Text

The Picture of [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray

by [Oscar Wilde]118-oscar wilde

THE PREFACE

[The artist]357-the artist is [the creator of beautiful things]358-the creator of beautiful things . To reveal art and conceal [the artist]357-the artist is art s aim . [The critic]360-the critic is [he]360-the critic who can translate into another manner or a new material [his]360-the critic impression of beautiful things .

The highest as the lowest form of criticism is a mode of autobiography . [Those who find ugly meanings in beautiful things]361-those who find ugly meanings in beautiful things are corrupt without being charming . This is a fault .

[Those who find beautiful meanings in beautiful things]362-those who find beautiful meanings in beautiful things are the cultivated . For these there is hope . [They]362-those who find beautiful meanings in beautiful things are [the elect to whom beautiful things mean only beauty]363-the elect to whom beautiful things mean only beauty .

There is no such thing as a moral or an immoral book . Books are well written , or badly written . That is all .

The nineteenth century dislike of realism is the rage of [Caliban]119-caliban seeing [his]119-caliban own face in a glass .

The nineteenth century dislike of romanticism is the rage of [Caliban]119-caliban not seeing [his]119-caliban own face in a glass . The moral life of [man]364-man forms part of the subject - matter of [the artist]357-the artist , but the morality of art consists in the perfect use of an imperfect medium . [No artist]366-no artist desires to prove anything . Even things that are true can be proved . [No artist]366-no artist has ethical sympathies . An ethical sympathy in [an artist]368-an artist is an unpardonable mannerism of style . [No artist]366-no artist is ever morbid . [The artist]357-the artist can express everything . Thought and language are to [the artist]357-the artist instruments of an art . Vice and virtue are to [the artist]357-the artist materials for an art . From the point of view of form , the type of all the arts is the art of [the musician]373-the musician . From the point of view of feeling , [the actor]374-the actor s craft is the type . All art is at once surface and symbol . Those who go beneath the surface do so at [their]361-those who find ugly meanings in beautiful things peril . [Those who read the symbol]375-those who read the symbol do so at [their]375-those who read the symbol peril . It is [the spectator]376-the spectator , and not life , that art really mirrors . Diversity of opinion about a work of art shows that the work is new , complex , and vital . When [critics]377-critics disagree , [the artist]357-the artist is in accord with [himself]357-the artist . [We]379-we can forgive [a man]380-a man for making a useful thing as long as [he]380-a man does not admire it . The only excuse for making a useless thing is that [one]381-one admires it intensely .

All art is quite useless .

[OSCAR WILDE]382-oscar wilde

CHAPTER I.

[The studio]383-the studio was filled with the rich odour of roses , and when the light summer wind stirred amidst the trees of [the garden]384-the garden , there came through the open door the heavy scent of the lilac , or the more delicate perfume of the pink - flowering thorn .

From the corner of the divan of Persian saddle - bags on which [he]357-the artist was lying , smoking , as was [his]357-the artist custom , innumerable cigarettes , [Lord Henry Wotton]120-lord henry could just catch the gleam of the honey - sweet and honey - coloured blossoms of a laburnum , whose tremulous branches seemed hardly able to bear the burden of a beauty so flamelike as theirs ; and now and then the fantastic shadows of birds in flight flitted across the long tussore - silk curtains that were stretched in front of the huge window , producing a kind of momentary Japanese effect , and making [him]357-the artist think of [those pallid , jade - faced painters of [Tokyo]1-tokyo]385-those pallid , jade - faced painters of tokyo who , through the medium of an art that is necessarily immobile , seek to convey the sense of swiftness and motion . The sullen murmur of the bees shouldering their way through the long unmown grass , or circling with monotonous insistence round the dusty gilt horns of the straggling woodbine , seemed to make the stillness more oppressive . The dim roar of [London]2-london was like the bourdon note of a distant organ .

In the centre of [the room]386-the room , clamped to an upright easel , stood the full - length portrait of [a young man of extraordinary personal beauty]387-a young man of extraordinary personal beauty , and in front of it , some little distance away , was sitting [the artist]357-the artist [himself]357-the artist , [Basil Hallward]121-basil , whose sudden disappearance some years ago caused , at the time , such public excitement and gave rise to so many strange conjectures .

As [the painter]389-the painter looked at the gracious and comely form [he]389-the painter had so skilfully mirrored in [his]389-the painter art , a smile of pleasure passed across [his]389-the painter face , and seemed about to linger there . But [he]389-the painter suddenly started up , and closing [his]389-the painter eyes , placed [his]389-the painter fingers upon the lids , as though [he]389-the painter sought to imprison within [his]389-the painter brain some curious dream from which [he]389-the painter feared [he]389-the painter might awake .

" It is [your]389-the painter best work , [Basil]121-basil , the best thing [you]389-the painter have ever done , "[120-lord henry] said [Lord Henry]120-lord henry languidly . " [You]389-the painter must certainly send it next year to [the Grosvenor]122-the grosvenor . [The Academy]1903-the academy is too large and too vulgar . Whenever [I]120-lord henry have gone [there]1904-there , there have been either so many people that [I]120-lord henry have not been able to see the pictures , which was dreadful , or so many pictures that [I]120-lord henry have not been able to see [the people]1905-the people , which was worse . [The Grosvenor]122-the grosvenor is really [the only place]1906-the only place . "[120-lord henry]

" [I]389-the painter don t think [I]389-the painter shall send it anywhere , "[389-the painter] [he]389-the painter answered , tossing [his]389-the painter head back in that odd way that used to make [[his]389-the painter friends]390-his friends laugh at [him]389-the painter at [Oxford]4-oxford . " No , [I]389-the painter won t send it anywhere . "[389-the painter]

[Lord Henry]120-lord henry elevated [his]120-lord henry eyebrows and looked at [him]389-the painter in amazement through the thin blue wreaths of smoke that curled up in such fanciful whorls from [his]120-lord henry heavy , opium - tainted cigarette . " Not send it anywhere ? [[My]120-lord henry dear fellow]1907-my dear fellow , why ? Have [you]1907-my dear fellow any reason ? What odd chaps [you]1907-my dear fellow painters are ! [You]1907-my dear fellow do anything in [the world]1908-the world to gain a reputation . As soon as [you]1907-my dear fellow have one , [you]1907-my dear fellow seem to want to throw it away . It is silly of [you]1907-my dear fellow , for there is only one thing in [the world]1908-the world worse than being talked about , and that is not being talked about . A portrait like this would set [you]1907-my dear fellow far above [all the young men in [England]5-england]1910-all the young men in england , and make [the old men]1911-the old men quite jealous , if [old men]1912-old men are ever capable of any emotion . "[120-lord henry]

" [I]389-the painter know [you]120-lord henry will laugh at [me]389-the painter , "[389-the painter] [he]389-the painter replied , " but [I]389-the painter really can t exhibit it . [I]389-the painter have put too much of [myself]389-the painter into it . "[389-the painter]

[Lord Henry]120-lord henry stretched [himself]120-lord henry out on the divan and laughed .

" Yes , [I]120-lord henry knew [you]120-lord henry would ; but it is quite true , all the same . "[120-lord henry]

" Too much of [yourself]1907-my dear fellow in it ! Upon [my]120-lord henry word , [Basil]121-basil , [I]120-lord henry didn t know [you]121-basil were so vain ; and [I]120-lord henry really can t see any resemblance between [you]121-basil , with [your]121-basil rugged strong face and [your]121-basil coal - black hair , and this young Adonis , who looks as if [he]1913-he was made out of ivory and rose - leaves . Why , [[my]120-lord henry dear]1914-my dear [Basil]121-basil , [he]1913-he is [a Narcissus]1915-a narcissus , and [you]121-basil well , of course [you]121-basil have an intellectual expression and all that . But beauty , real beauty , ends where an intellectual expression begins . Intellect is in itself a mode of exaggeration , and destroys the harmony of any face . The moment [one]381-one sits down to think , [one]381-one becomes all nose , or all forehead , or something horrid . Look at [the successful men in any of the learned professions]1918-the successful men in any of the learned professions . How perfectly hideous [they]1918-the successful men in any of the learned professions are ! Except , of course , in [the Church]1919-the church . But then in [the Church]1919-the church [they]1918-the successful men in any of the learned professions don t think . [A bishop]1921-a bishop keeps on saying at the age of eighty what [he]1921-a bishop was told to say when [he]1921-a bishop was [a boy of eighteen]1922-a boy of eighteen , and as a natural consequence [he]1921-a bishop always looks absolutely delightful . [[Your]121-basil mysterious young friend , whose name [you]121-basil have never told [me]120-lord henry , but whose picture really fascinates [me]120-lord henry]1923-your mysterious young friend , whose name you have never told me , but whose picture really fascinates me , never thinks . [I]120-lord henry feel quite sure of that . [He]1923-your mysterious young friend , whose name you have never told me , but whose picture really fascinates me is [some brainless beautiful creature who should be always here in winter when [we]1925-we have no flowers to look at , and always here in summer when [we]1925-we want something to chill [our]1925-we intelligence]1924-some brainless beautiful creature who should be always here in winter when we have no flowers to look at , and always here in summer when we want something to chill our intelligence . Don t flatter [yourself]121-basil , [Basil]121-basil : [you]121-basil are not in the least like [him]1923-your mysterious young friend , whose name you have never told me , but whose picture really fascinates me . "[120-lord henry]

" [You]121-basil don t understand [me]357-the artist , [Harry]120-lord henry , "[357-the artist] answered [the artist]357-the artist . " Of course [I]357-the artist am not like [him]1923-your mysterious young friend , whose name you have never told me , but whose picture really fascinates me . [I]357-the artist know that perfectly well . Indeed , [I]357-the artist should be sorry to look like [him]1923-your mysterious young friend , whose name you have never told me , but whose picture really fascinates me . [You]121-basil shrug [your]121-basil shoulders ? [I]357-the artist am telling [you]121-basil the truth . There is a fatality about all physical and intellectual distinction , the sort of fatality that seems to dog through history the faltering steps of [kings]1926-kings . It is better not to be different from [one s fellows]1927-one s fellows . [The ugly and the stupid]1928-the ugly and the stupid have the best of it in [this world]1929-this world . [They]1928-the ugly and the stupid can sit at [their]1928-the ugly and the stupid ease and gape at the play . If [they]1928-the ugly and the stupid know nothing of victory , [they]1928-the ugly and the stupid are at least spared the knowledge of defeat . [They]1928-the ugly and the stupid live as [we]1930-we all should live undisturbed , indifferent , and without disquiet . [They]1928-the ugly and the stupid neither bring ruin upon [others]1931-others , nor ever receive it from alien hands . [Your]121-basil rank and wealth , [Harry]120-lord henry ; [my]357-the artist brains , such as they are [my]357-the artist art , whatever it may be worth ; [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray s good looks [we]1930-we shall all suffer for what [the gods]1932-the gods have given [us]1930-we , suffer terribly . "[357-the artist]

" [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray ? Is that [his]117-dorian gray name ? "[120-lord henry] asked [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , walking across [the studio]383-the studio towards [Basil Hallward]121-basil .

" Yes , that is [his]117-dorian gray name . [I]120-lord henry didn t intend to tell it to [you]121-basil . "[120-lord henry]

" But why not ? "[120-lord henry]

" Oh , [I]120-lord henry can t explain . When [I]120-lord henry like [people]1933-people immensely , [I]120-lord henry never tell [their]1933-people names to [any one]1934-any one . It is like surrendering a part of [them]1933-people . [I]120-lord henry have grown to love secrecy . It seems to be the one thing that can make modern life mysterious or marvellous to [us]1930-we . The commonest thing is delightful if one only hides it . When [I]120-lord henry leave [town]1935-town now [I]120-lord henry never tell [[my]120-lord henry people]1936-my people where [I]120-lord henry am going . If [I]120-lord henry did , [I]120-lord henry would lose all [my]120-lord henry pleasure . It is a silly habit , [I]120-lord henry dare say , but somehow it seems to bring a great deal of romance into one s life . [I]120-lord henry suppose [you]120-lord henry think [me]120-lord henry awfully foolish about it ? "[120-lord henry]

" Not at all , "[120-lord henry] answered [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , " not at all , [[my]120-lord henry dear]1914-my dear [Basil]121-basil . [You]121-basil seem to forget that [I]120-lord henry am married , and the one charm of marriage is that it makes a life of deception absolutely necessary for [both parties]1938-both parties . [I]120-lord henry never know where [[my]120-lord henry wife]1939-my wife is , and [[my]120-lord henry wife]1939-my wife never knows what [I]120-lord henry am doing . When [we]1941-we meet [we]1941-we do meet occasionally , when [we]1941-we dine out together , or go down to the Duke s [we]1941-we tell [each other]1942-each other the most absurd stories with the most serious faces . [[My]120-lord henry wife]1939-my wife is very good at it much better , in fact , than [I]120-lord henry am . [She]1939-my wife never gets confused over [her]1939-my wife dates , and [I]120-lord henry always do . But when [she]1939-my wife does find [me]120-lord henry out , [she]1939-my wife makes no row at all . [I]120-lord henry sometimes wish [she]1939-my wife would ; but [she]1939-my wife merely laughs at [me]120-lord henry . "[120-lord henry]

" [I]121-basil hate the way [you]121-basil talk about [your]121-basil married life , [Harry]120-lord henry , "[121-basil] said [Basil Hallward]121-basil , strolling towards the door that led into [the garden]384-the garden . " [I]121-basil believe that [you]121-basil are really [a very good husband]1944-a very good husband , but that [you]121-basil are thoroughly ashamed of [your]121-basil own virtues . [You]121-basil are [an extraordinary fellow]1945-an extraordinary fellow . [You]121-basil never say a moral thing , and [you]121-basil never do a wrong thing . [Your]121-basil cynicism is simply a pose . "[121-basil]

" Being natural is simply a pose , and the most irritating pose [I]120-lord henry know , "[120-lord henry] cried [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , laughing ; and [the two young men]394-the two young men went out into [the garden]384-the garden together and ensconced [themselves]394-the two young men on a long bamboo seat that stood in the shade of a tall laurel bush . The sunlight slipped over the polished leaves . In the grass , white daisies were tremulous .

After a pause , [Lord Henry]120-lord henry pulled out [his]120-lord henry watch . " [I]120-lord henry am afraid [I]120-lord henry must be going , [Basil]121-basil , "[120-lord henry] [he]120-lord henry murmured , " and before [I]120-lord henry go , [I]120-lord henry insist on [your]121-basil answering a question [I]120-lord henry put to [you]121-basil some time ago . "[120-lord henry]

" What is that ? "[389-the painter] said [the painter]389-the painter , keeping [his]389-the painter eyes fixed on the ground .

" [You]389-the painter know quite well . "[120-lord henry]

" [I]389-the painter do not , [Harry]120-lord henry . "[389-the painter]

" Well , [I]120-lord henry will tell [you]121-basil what it is . [I]120-lord henry want [you]121-basil to explain to [me]120-lord henry why [you]121-basil won t exhibit [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray s picture . [I]120-lord henry want the real reason . "[120-lord henry]

" [I]389-the painter told [you]121-basil the real reason . "[389-the painter]

" No , [you]121-basil did not . [You]121-basil said it was because there was too much of [yourself]121-basil in it . Now , that is childish . "[120-lord henry]

" [Harry]120-lord henry , "[121-basil] said [Basil Hallward]121-basil , looking [him]389-the painter straight in the face , " every portrait that is painted with feeling is a portrait of [the artist]357-the artist , not of [the sitter]1947-the sitter . [The sitter]1947-the sitter is merely the accident , the occasion . It is not [he]1947-the sitter who is revealed by [the painter]389-the painter ; it is rather [the painter who , on the coloured canvas , reveals [himself]1950-the painter who , on the coloured canvas , reveals himself]1950-the painter who , on the coloured canvas , reveals himself . The reason [I]121-basil will not exhibit this picture is that [I]121-basil am afraid that [I]121-basil have shown in it the secret of [my]121-basil own soul . "[121-basil]

[Lord Henry]120-lord henry laughed . " And what is that ? "[120-lord henry] [he]120-lord henry asked .

" [I]121-basil will tell [you]120-lord henry , "[121-basil] said [Hallward]121-basil ; but an expression of perplexity came over [his]121-basil face .

" [I]397-his companion am all expectation , [Basil]121-basil , "[397-his companion] continued [[his]120-lord henry companion]397-his companion , glancing at [him]120-lord henry .

" Oh , there is really very little to tell , [Harry]120-lord henry , "[389-the painter] answered [the painter]389-the painter ; " and [I]389-the painter am afraid [you]120-lord henry will hardly understand it . Perhaps [you]120-lord henry will hardly believe it . "[389-the painter]

[Lord Henry]120-lord henry smiled , and leaning down , plucked a pink - petalled daisy from the grass and examined it . " [I]120-lord henry am quite sure [I]120-lord henry shall understand it , "[120-lord henry] [he]120-lord henry replied , gazing intently at the little golden , white - feathered disk , " and as for believing things , [I]120-lord henry can believe anything , provided that it is quite incredible . "[120-lord henry]

The wind shook some blossoms from the trees , and the heavy lilac - blooms , with their clustering stars , moved to and fro in the languid air . A grasshopper began to chirrup by the wall , and like a blue thread a long thin dragon - fly floated past on its brown gauze wings . [Lord Henry]120-lord henry felt as if [he]120-lord henry could hear [Basil Hallward]121-basil s heart beating , and wondered what was coming .

" The story is simply this , "[389-the painter] said [the painter]389-the painter after some time . " Two months ago [I]389-the painter went to a crush at [Lady Brandon]123-lady brandon s. [You]120-lord henry know [we]1951-we [poor artists]1952-poor artists have to show [ourselves]1951-we in society from time to time , just to remind [the public]1953-the public that [we]1951-we are [not savages]1954-not savages . With an evening coat and a white tie , as [you]120-lord henry told [me]389-the painter once , [anybody]1955-anybody , even [a stock - broker]1956-a stock - broker , can gain a reputation for being civilized . Well , after [I]389-the painter had been in [the room]386-the room about ten minutes , talking to [huge overdressed dowagers]1958-huge overdressed dowagers and [tedious academicians]1959-tedious academicians , [I]389-the painter suddenly became conscious that [some one]1960-some one was looking at [me]389-the painter . [I]389-the painter turned half - way round and saw [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray for the first time . When [our]1961-our eyes met , [I]389-the painter felt that [I]389-the painter was growing pale . A curious sensation of terror came over [me]389-the painter . [I]389-the painter knew that [I]389-the painter had come face to face with [some one whose mere personality]1962-some one whose mere personality was so fascinating that , if [I]389-the painter allowed it to do so , it would absorb [my]389-the painter whole nature , [my]389-the painter whole soul , [my]389-the painter very art itself . [I]389-the painter did not want any external influence in [my]389-the painter life . [You]1963-you know [yourself]1963-you , [Harry]120-lord henry , how independent [I]389-the painter am by nature . [I]389-the painter have always been [[my]389-the painter own master]1964-my own master ; had at least always been so , till [I]389-the painter met [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray . Then but [I]389-the painter don t know how to explain it to [you]1963-you . Something seemed to tell [me]389-the painter that [I]389-the painter was on the verge of a terrible crisis in [my]389-the painter life . [I]389-the painter had a strange feeling that fate had in store for [me]389-the painter exquisite joys and exquisite sorrows . [I]389-the painter grew afraid and turned to quit [the room]386-the room . It was not conscience that made [me]389-the painter do so : it was a sort of cowardice . [I]389-the painter take no credit to [myself]389-the painter for trying to escape . "[389-the painter]

" Conscience and cowardice are really the same things , [Basil]121-basil . [Conscience]124-conscience is the trade - name of [the firm]1966-the firm . That is all . "[389-the painter]

" [I]389-the painter don t believe that , [Harry]120-lord henry , and [I]389-the painter don t believe [you]120-lord henry do either . There , of course , [I]389-the painter stumbled against [Lady Brandon]123-lady brandon . [You]120-lord henry are not going to run away so soon , [Mr. Hallward]125-mr. hallward ? " [I]389-the painter could not get rid of [her]123-lady brandon . Suddenly [I]389-the painter found [myself]389-the painter face to face with [the young man whose personality had so strangely stirred [me]389-the painter]1970-the young man whose personality had so strangely stirred me . " [I]389-the painter sometimes think , [Harry]120-lord henry , that there are only two eras of any importance in [the world s]2027-the world s history . The first is the appearance of a new medium for art , and the second is the appearance of a new personality for art also . " Days in summer , [Basil]121-basil , are apt to linger , "[120-lord henry] murmured [Lord Henry]120-lord henry . " Perhaps [you]121-basil will tire sooner than [he]117-dorian gray will . It is a sad thing to think of , but there is no doubt that genius lasts longer than beauty . That accounts for the fact that [we]2045-we all take such pains to over - educate [ourselves]2045-we . In the wild struggle for existence , [we]2045-we want to have something that endures , and so [we]2045-we fill [our]2045-we minds with rubbish and facts , in the silly hope of keeping [our]2045-we place . [The thoroughly well - informed man that is the modern ideal]2048-the thoroughly well - informed man that is the modern ideal . "[120-lord henry] And [Lord Henry]120-lord henry struck a light on a dainty silver case and began to smoke a cigarette with a self - conscious and satisfied air , as if [he]120-lord henry had summed up [the world]1908-the world in a phrase . How pleasant it was in [the garden]384-the garden ! And how delightful [other people]2010-other people s emotions were ! much more delightful than [their]2010-other people ideas , it seemed to [him]120-lord henry . [Each class]415-each class would have preached the importance of those virtues , for whose exercise there was no necessity in [their]415-each class own lives . [The rich]416-the rich would have spoken on the value of thrift , and [the idle]417-the idle grown eloquent over the dignity of labour . It was charming to have escaped all that ! [I]418-his aunt am bound to state that [she]131-lady agatha never told [me]418-his aunt [he]2057-a wonderful young man who was going to help her in the east end was good - looking . [Women]2058-women have no appreciation of good looks ; at least , [good women]2059-good women have not . "[117-dorian gray]

" There is no such thing as a good influence , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray . All influence is immoral immoral from the scientific point of view . "[120-lord henry]

" Why ? "[117-dorian gray]

" Because to influence [a person]2094-a person is to give [him]2094-a person one s own soul . [He]2094-a person does not think [his]2094-a person natural thoughts , or burn with [his]2094-a person natural passions . [His]2094-a person virtues are not real to [him]2094-a person . The aim of life is self - development . To realize one s nature perfectly that is what each of [us]2097-us is here for . [People]1933-people are afraid of [themselves]1933-people , nowadays . [They]1933-people have forgotten the highest of all duties , the duty that [one]381-one owes to [one s self]2100-one s self . Of course , [they]1933-people are charitable . [They]1933-people feed the hungry and clothe [the beggar]2101-the beggar . But [their]1933-people own souls starve , and are naked . Courage has gone out of [our]2097-us race . Perhaps [we]2097-us never really had it . " Just turn [your]427-the lad head a little more to the right , [Dorian]2102-dorian , like [a good boy]2103-a good boy , "[389-the painter] said [the painter]389-the painter , deep in [his]389-the painter work and conscious only that a look had come into [the lad]427-the lad s face that [he]389-the painter had never seen there before .

" And yet , "[120-lord henry] continued [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , in [his]120-lord henry low , musical voice , and with that graceful wave of the hand that was always so characteristic of [him]120-lord henry , and that [he]120-lord henry had even in [his]120-lord henry Eton days , " [I]120-lord henry believe that if [one man]2104-one man were to live out [his]2104-one man life fully and completely , were to give form to every feeling , expression to every thought , reality to every dream [I]120-lord henry believe that [the world]1908-the world would gain such a fresh impulse of joy that [we]2097-us would forget all the maladies of medi valism , and return to the Hellenic ideal to something finer , richer than the Hellenic ideal , it may be . But [the bravest man amongst [us]2097-us]2106-the bravest man amongst us is afraid of [himself]2106-the bravest man amongst us . The mutilation of [the savage]2107-the savage has its tragic survival in the self - denial that mars [our]2097-us lives . [We]2097-us are punished for [our]2097-us refusals . Every impulse that [we]2097-us strive to strangle broods in the mind and poisons [us]2097-us . The body sins once , and has done with [its]2108-its sin , for action is a mode of purification . Nothing remains then but the recollection of a pleasure , or the luxury of a regret . The only way to get rid of a temptation is to yield to it . Resist it , and [your]2109-you soul grows sick with longing for the things it has forbidden to itself , with desire for what its monstrous laws have made monstrous and unlawful . It has been said that the great events of [the world]1908-the world take place in the brain . It is in the brain , and the brain only , that the great sins of [the world]1908-the world take place also . [You]2109-you , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray , [you]2109-you [yourself]2109-you , with [your]2109-you rose - red youth and [your]2109-you rose - white boyhood , [you]2109-you have had passions that have made [you]2109-you afraid , thoughts that have filled [you]2109-you with terror , day - dreams and sleeping dreams whose mere memory might stain [your]2109-you cheek with shame "[120-lord henry]

" Stop ! "[117-dorian gray] faltered [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray , " stop ! [you]2109-you bewilder [me]117-dorian gray . [I]117-dorian gray don t know what to say . "[117-dorian gray]

For nearly ten minutes [he]117-dorian gray stood there , motionless , with parted lips and eyes strangely bright . [He]117-dorian gray was dimly conscious that entirely fresh influences were at work within [him]117-dorian gray . Yet they seemed to [him]117-dorian gray to have come really from [himself]117-dorian gray . The few words that [[Basil]121-basil s friend]439-basil s friend had said to [him]117-dorian gray words spoken by chance , no doubt , and with wilful paradox in them had touched some secret chord that had never been touched before , but that [he]117-dorian gray felt was now vibrating and throbbing to curious pulses .

Music had stirred [him]117-dorian gray like that . Music had troubled [him]117-dorian gray many times . But music was not articulate . It was not [a new world]440-a new world , but rather another chaos , that it created in [us]441-us . Words ! Mere words ! How terrible they were ! How clear , and vivid , and cruel ! [One]381-one could not escape from [them]443-them . And yet what a subtle magic there was in them ! [They]443-them seemed to be able to give a plastic form to formless things , and to have a music of [their]443-them own as sweet as that of viol or of lute . Mere words ! Was there anything so real as words ?

Yes ; there had been things in [his]117-dorian gray boyhood that [he]117-dorian gray had not understood . [He]117-dorian gray understood them now . Life suddenly became fiery - coloured to [him]117-dorian gray . It seemed to [him]117-dorian gray that [he]117-dorian gray had been walking in fire . Why had [he]117-dorian gray not known it ?

With [his]117-dorian gray subtle smile , [Lord Henry]120-lord henry watched [him]117-dorian gray . [He]117-dorian gray knew the precise psychological moment when to say nothing . [He]117-dorian gray felt intensely interested . [He]117-dorian gray was amazed at the sudden impression that [his]117-dorian gray words had produced , and , remembering a book that [he]117-dorian gray had read when [he]117-dorian gray was sixteen , a book which had revealed to [him]117-dorian gray much that [he]117-dorian gray had not known before , [he]117-dorian gray wondered whether [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray was passing through a similar experience . [He]117-dorian gray had merely shot an arrow into the air . Had it hit the mark ? How fascinating [the lad]427-the lad was !

[Hallward]121-basil painted away with that marvellous bold touch of [his]121-basil , that had the true refinement and perfect delicacy that in art , at any rate comes only from strength . [He]121-basil was unconscious of the silence .

" [Basil]121-basil , [I]117-dorian gray am tired of standing , "[117-dorian gray] cried [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray suddenly . " [I]117-dorian gray must go out and sit in [the garden]384-the garden . The air is stifling here . "[117-dorian gray]

" [[My]427-the lad dear fellow]1907-my dear fellow , [I]427-the lad am so sorry . When [I]427-the lad am painting , [I]427-the lad can t think of anything else . But [you]1907-my dear fellow never sat better . [You]1907-my dear fellow were perfectly still . And [I]427-the lad have caught the effect [I]427-the lad wanted the half - parted lips and the bright look in the eyes . [Lord Henry]120-lord henry went out to [the garden]384-the garden and found [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray burying [his]117-dorian gray face in the great cool lilac - blossoms , feverishly drinking in their perfume as if it had been wine . " [You]120-lord henry are quite right to do that , "[120-lord henry] [he]120-lord henry murmured . " Nothing can cure the soul but the senses , just as nothing can cure the senses but the soul . "[120-lord henry]

[The lad]427-the lad started and drew back . [He]427-the lad was bareheaded , and the leaves had tossed [his]427-the lad rebellious curls and tangled all their gilded threads . There was a look of fear in [his]427-the lad eyes , such as [people]1933-people have when [they]1933-people are suddenly awakened . [His]427-the lad finely chiselled nostrils quivered , and some hidden nerve shook the scarlet of [his]427-the lad lips and left them trembling .

" Yes , "[120-lord henry] continued [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , " that is one of the great secrets of life to cure the soul by means of the senses , and the senses by means of the soul . [You]120-lord henry are [a wonderful creation]2118-a wonderful creation . [You]120-lord henry know more than [you]120-lord henry think [you]120-lord henry know , just as [you]120-lord henry know less than [you]120-lord henry want to know . "[120-lord henry]

[Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray frowned and turned [his]117-dorian gray head away . [He]117-dorian gray could not help liking [the tall , graceful young man who was standing by [him]117-dorian gray]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him . [His]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him romantic , olive - coloured face and worn expression interested [him]117-dorian gray . There was something in [his]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him low languid voice that was absolutely fascinating . [His]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him cool , white , flowerlike hands , even , had a curious charm . [They]450-they moved , as [he]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him spoke , like music , and seemed to have a language of [their]450-they own . But [he]117-dorian gray felt afraid of [him]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him , and ashamed of being afraid . Why had it been left for [a stranger]451-a stranger to reveal [him]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him to [himself]449-the tall , graceful young man who was standing by him ? [He]117-dorian gray had known [Basil Hallward]121-basil for months , but the friendship between [them]452-them had never altered [him]117-dorian gray . Suddenly there had come some one across [his]117-dorian gray life who seemed to have disclosed to [him]117-dorian gray life s mystery . And , yet , what was there to be afraid of ? [He]117-dorian gray was not [a schoolboy]453-a schoolboy or [a girl]454-a girl . It was absurd to be frightened .

" Let [us]452-them go and sit in the shade , "[120-lord henry] said [Lord Henry]120-lord henry . " [Parker]132-parker has brought out the drinks , and if [you]117-dorian gray stay any longer in this glare , [you]117-dorian gray will be quite spoiled , and [Basil]121-basil will never paint [you]117-dorian gray again . [You]117-dorian gray really must not allow [yourself]117-dorian gray to become sunburnt . It would be unbecoming . "[120-lord henry]

" What can it matter ? "[117-dorian gray] cried [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray , laughing , as [he]117-dorian gray sat down on the seat at the end of [the garden]384-the garden .

" It should matter everything to [you]117-dorian gray , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray . "[120-lord henry]

" Why ? "[120-lord henry]

" Because [you]117-dorian gray have the most marvellous youth , and youth is the one thing worth having . "[120-lord henry]

" [I]120-lord henry don t feel that , [Lord Henry]120-lord henry . "[120-lord henry]

" No , [you]117-dorian gray don t feel it now . Some day , when [you]117-dorian gray are old and wrinkled and ugly , when thought has seared [your]117-dorian gray forehead with its lines , and passion branded [your]117-dorian gray lips with its hideous fires , [you]117-dorian gray will feel it , [you]117-dorian gray will feel it terribly . Now , wherever [you]117-dorian gray go , [you]117-dorian gray charm [the world]1908-the world . Will it always be so ? ... [You]117-dorian gray have a wonderfully beautiful face , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray . Don t frown . [You]117-dorian gray have . And beauty is a form of genius is higher , indeed , than genius , as it needs no explanation . It is of the great facts of [the world]1908-the world , like sunlight , or spring - time , or the reflection in dark waters of that silver shell [we]2121-we call the moon . It can not be questioned . It has its divine right of sovereignty . It makes princes of [those who have it]2122-those who have it . [You]117-dorian gray smile ? Ah ! when [you]117-dorian gray have lost it [you]117-dorian gray won t smile .... [People]1933-people say sometimes that beauty is only superficial . That may be so , but at least it is not so superficial as thought is . To [me]120-lord henry , beauty is the wonder of wonders . It is only [shallow people who do not judge by appearances]2124-shallow people who do not judge by appearances . The true mystery of [the world]1908-the world is the visible , not the invisible .... Yes , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray , [the gods]1932-the gods have been good to [you]117-dorian gray . But what [the gods]1932-the gods give [they]1932-the gods quickly take away . [You]117-dorian gray have only a few years in which to live really , perfectly , and fully . When [your]117-dorian gray youth goes , [your]117-dorian gray beauty will go with it , and then [you]117-dorian gray will suddenly discover that there are no triumphs left for [you]117-dorian gray , or have to content [yourself]117-dorian gray with those mean triumphs that the memory of [your]117-dorian gray past will make more bitter than defeats . Every month as it wanes brings [you]117-dorian gray nearer to something dreadful . Time is jealous of [you]117-dorian gray , and wars against [your]117-dorian gray lilies and [your]117-dorian gray roses . [You]117-dorian gray will become sallow , and hollow - cheeked , and dull - eyed . [You]117-dorian gray will suffer horribly .... Ah ! realize [your]117-dorian gray youth while [you]117-dorian gray have it . Don t squander the gold of [your]117-dorian gray days , listening to the tedious , trying to improve the hopeless failure , or giving away [your]117-dorian gray life to [the ignorant]2128-the ignorant , [the common]2129-the common , and [the vulgar]2130-the vulgar . These are the sickly aims , the false ideals , of [our]2131-our age . Live ! Live the wonderful life that is in [you]117-dorian gray ! Let nothing be lost upon [you]117-dorian gray . Be always searching for new sensations . Be afraid of nothing .... A new Hedonism that is what [our]2131-our century wants . [You]117-dorian gray might be its visible symbol . With [your]117-dorian gray personality there is nothing [you]117-dorian gray could not do . [The world]1908-the world belongs to [you]117-dorian gray for a season .... The moment [I]120-lord henry met [you]117-dorian gray [I]120-lord henry saw that [you]117-dorian gray were quite unconscious of what [you]117-dorian gray really are , of what [you]117-dorian gray really might be . There was so much in [you]117-dorian gray that charmed [me]120-lord henry that [I]120-lord henry felt [I]120-lord henry must tell [you]117-dorian gray something about [yourself]117-dorian gray . [I]120-lord henry thought how tragic it would be if [you]117-dorian gray were wasted . For there is such a little time that [your]117-dorian gray youth will last such a little time . The common hill - flowers wither , but they blossom again . The laburnum will be as yellow next June as it is now . In a month there will be purple stars on the clematis , and year after year the green night of its leaves will hold its purple stars . But [we]2133-we never get back [our]2133-we youth . The pulse of joy that beats in [us]2133-we at twenty becomes sluggish . [Our]2133-we limbs fail , [our]2133-we senses rot . [We]2133-we degenerate into hideous puppets , haunted by the memory of the passions of which [we]2133-we were too much afraid , and the exquisite temptations that [we]2133-we had not the courage to yield to . [Youth]135-youth ! Youth ! There is absolutely nothing in [the world]1908-the world but youth ! "[120-lord henry]

[Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray listened , open - eyed and wondering . The spray of lilac fell from [his]117-dorian gray hand upon the gravel . A furry bee came and buzzed round it for a moment . Then it began to scramble all over the oval stellated globe of the tiny blossoms . [He]117-dorian gray watched it with that strange interest in trivial things that [we]456-we try to develop when things of high import make [us]456-we afraid , or when [we]456-we are stirred by some new emotion for which [we]456-we can not find expression , or when some thought that terrifies [us]456-we lays sudden siege to the brain and calls on [us]456-we to yield . After a time the bee flew away . [He]117-dorian gray saw it creeping into the stained trumpet of a Tyrian convolvulus . The flower seemed to quiver , and then swayed gently to and fro .

Suddenly [the painter]389-the painter appeared at the door of [the studio]383-the studio and made staccato signs for [them]459-they to come in . [They]459-they turned to [each other]1942-each other and smiled .

" [I]389-the painter am waiting , "[389-the painter] [he]389-the painter cried . " Do come in . The light is quite perfect , and [you]459-they can bring [your]459-they drinks . "[389-the painter]

[They]459-they rose up and sauntered down [the walk]424-the walk together . Two green - and - white butterflies fluttered past [them]459-they , and in the pear - tree at the corner of [the garden]384-the garden a thrush began to sing .

" [You]117-dorian gray are glad [you]117-dorian gray have met [me]120-lord henry , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray , "[120-lord henry] said [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , looking at [him]117-dorian gray .

" Yes , [I]120-lord henry am glad now . [I]120-lord henry wonder shall [I]120-lord henry always be glad ? "[120-lord henry]

" Always ! That is a dreadful word . It makes [me]120-lord henry shudder when [I]120-lord henry hear it . [Women]2058-women are so fond of using it . [They]2058-women spoil every romance by trying to make it last for ever . It is a meaningless word , too . The only difference between a caprice and a lifelong passion is that the caprice lasts a little longer . "[120-lord henry]

As [they]459-they entered [the studio]383-the studio , [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray put [his]117-dorian gray hand upon [Lord Henry]120-lord henry s arm . " In that case , let [our]459-they friendship be a caprice , "[117-dorian gray] [he]117-dorian gray murmured , flushing at [his]117-dorian gray own boldness , then stepped up on the platform and resumed [his]117-dorian gray pose .

[Lord Henry]120-lord henry flung [himself]120-lord henry into a large wicker arm - chair and watched [him]117-dorian gray . The sweep and dash of the brush on the canvas made the only sound that broke the stillness , except when , now and then , [Hallward]121-basil stepped back to look at [his]121-basil work from a distance . In the slanting beams that streamed through the open doorway the dust danced and was golden . The heavy scent of the roses seemed to brood over everything .

After about a quarter of an hour [Hallward]121-basil stopped painting , looked for a long time at [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray , and then for a long time at the picture , biting the end of one of [his]121-basil huge brushes and frowning . " It is quite finished , "[121-basil] [he]121-basil cried at last , and stooping down [he]121-basil wrote [his]121-basil name in long vermilion letters on the left - hand corner of the canvas .

[Lord Henry]120-lord henry came over and examined the picture . It was certainly a wonderful work of art , and a wonderful likeness as well .

" [[My]120-lord henry dear fellow]1907-my dear fellow , [I]120-lord henry congratulate [you]1907-my dear fellow most warmly , "[120-lord henry] [he]120-lord henry said . " It is the finest portrait of modern times . [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray , come over and look at [yourself]1907-my dear fellow . "[120-lord henry]

[The lad]427-the lad started , as if awakened from some dream .

" Is it really finished ? "[120-lord henry] [he]120-lord henry murmured , stepping down from [the platform]465-the platform .

" Quite finished , "[389-the painter] said [the painter]389-the painter . " And [you]1907-my dear fellow have sat splendidly to - day . [I]389-the painter am awfully obliged to [you]1907-my dear fellow . "[389-the painter]

" That is entirely due to [me]120-lord henry , "[120-lord henry] broke in [Lord Henry]120-lord henry . " Isn t it , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray ? "[120-lord henry]

[Dorian]117-dorian gray made no answer , but passed listlessly in front of [his]117-dorian gray picture and turned towards it . When [he]117-dorian gray saw it [he]117-dorian gray drew back , and [his]117-dorian gray cheeks flushed for a moment with pleasure . A look of joy came into [his]117-dorian gray eyes , as if [he]117-dorian gray had recognized [himself]117-dorian gray for the first time . [He]117-dorian gray stood there motionless and in wonder , dimly conscious that [Hallward]121-basil was speaking to [him]117-dorian gray , but not catching the meaning of [his]121-basil words . The sense of [his]117-dorian gray own beauty came on [him]117-dorian gray like a revelation . [He]117-dorian gray had never felt it before . [Basil Hallward]121-basil s compliments had seemed to [him]117-dorian gray to be merely the charming exaggeration of friendship . [He]117-dorian gray had listened to [them]467-them , laughed at [them]467-them , forgotten [them]467-them . [They]467-them had not influenced [his]117-dorian gray nature . Then had come [Lord Henry Wotton]120-lord henry with [his]120-lord henry strange panegyric on youth , [his]120-lord henry terrible warning of its brevity . That had stirred [him]117-dorian gray at the time , and now , as [he]117-dorian gray stood gazing at the shadow of [his]117-dorian gray own loveliness , the full reality of the description flashed across [him]117-dorian gray . Yes , there would be a day when [his]117-dorian gray face would be wrinkled and wizen , [his]117-dorian gray eyes dim and colourless , the grace of [his]117-dorian gray figure broken and deformed . The scarlet would pass away from [his]117-dorian gray lips and the gold steal from [his]117-dorian gray hair . The life that was to make [his]117-dorian gray soul would mar [his]117-dorian gray body . [He]117-dorian gray would become dreadful , hideous , and uncouth .

As [he]117-dorian gray thought of it , a sharp pang of pain struck through [him]117-dorian gray like a knife and made each delicate fibre of [his]117-dorian gray nature quiver . [His]117-dorian gray eyes deepened into amethyst , and across them came a mist of tears . [He]117-dorian gray felt as if a hand of ice had been laid upon [his]117-dorian gray heart .

" Don t [you]427-the lad like it ? "[121-basil] cried [Hallward]121-basil at last , stung a little by [the lad]427-the lad s silence , not understanding what it meant .

[I]117-dorian gray shall grow old , and horrible , and dreadful . But this picture will remain always young . It will never be older than this particular day of June .... " [You]2177-dorian won t forget ? "[121-basil]

" No , of course not , "[485-dorian] cried [Dorian]485-dorian .

" And ... [Harry]120-lord henry ! "[121-basil]

" Yes , [Basil]121-basil ? "[121-basil]

" Remember what [I]121-basil asked [you]121-basil , when [we]484-them were in [the garden]384-the garden this morning . "[121-basil]

" [I]121-basil have forgotten it . "[121-basil]

" [I]121-basil trust [you]121-basil . "[121-basil]

" [I]120-lord henry wish [I]120-lord henry could trust [myself]120-lord henry , "[120-lord henry] said [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , laughing . Good - bye , [Basil]121-basil . It has been a most interesting afternoon . "[120-lord henry]

As the door closed behind [them]486-them , [the painter]389-the painter flung [himself]389-the painter down on a sofa , and a look of pain came into [his]389-the painter face .

CHAPTER III .

At half - past twelve next day [Lord Henry Wotton]120-lord henry strolled from [Curzon Street]10-curzon street over to [the Albany]488-the albany to call on [[his]120-lord henry uncle]489-his uncle , [Lord Fermor]136-lord fermor , [a genial if somewhat rough - mannered old bachelor , whom [the outside world]491-the outside world called selfish because it derived no particular benefit from [him]489-his uncle]490-a genial if somewhat rough - mannered old bachelor , whom the outside world called selfish because it derived no particular benefit from him , but who was considered generous by [Society]137-society as [he]489-his uncle fed [the people who amused [him]489-his uncle]492-the people who amused him . [[His]120-lord henry father]493-his father had been [[our]494-our ambassador]495-our ambassador at [Madrid]12-madrid when [Isabella]138-isabella was young and Prim unthought of , but had retired from the diplomatic service in a capricious moment of annoyance on not being offered the Embassy at [Paris]13-paris , a post to which [he]493-his father considered that [he]493-his father was fully entitled by reason of [his]493-his father birth , [his]493-his father indolence , the good English of [his]493-his father dispatches , and [his]493-his father inordinate passion for pleasure . [The son]496-the son , who had been [[his]496-the son father s secretary]497-his father s secretary , had resigned along with [[his]496-the son chief]498-his chief , somewhat foolishly as was thought at the time , and on succeeding some months later to the title , had set [himself]496-the son to the serious study of the great aristocratic art of doing absolutely nothing . [He]493-his father had [two large town houses]499-two large town houses , but preferred to live in [chambers]500-chambers as it was less trouble , and took most of [his]493-his father meals at [[his]493-his father club]501-his club . [He]493-his father paid some attention to the management of [[his]493-his father collieries]502-his collieries in [the Midland counties]503-the midland counties , excusing [himself]493-his father for this taint of industry on the ground that the one advantage of having coal was that it enabled [a gentleman]504-a gentleman to afford the decency of burning wood on [his]504-a gentleman own hearth . In politics [he]493-his father was [a Tory]505-a tory , except when [the Tories]506-the tories were in office , during which period [he]493-his father roundly abused [them]506-the tories for being [a pack of Radicals]507-a pack of radicals . [He]493-his father was [a hero to [[his]493-his father valet]509-his valet , who bullied [him]493-his father , and a terror to most of [[his]493-his father relations]510-his relations , whom [he]493-his father bullied in turn]508-a hero to his valet , who bullied him , and a terror to most of his relations , whom he bullied in turn . Only [England]5-england could have produced [him]493-his father , and [he]493-his father always said that [the country]511-the country was going to the dogs . [His]493-his father principles were out of date , but there was a good deal to be said for [his]493-his father prejudices .

When [Lord Henry]120-lord henry entered [the room]386-the room , [he]120-lord henry found [[his]120-lord henry uncle]489-his uncle sitting in a rough shooting - coat , smoking a cheroot and grumbling over _ The Times _ . " Well , [Harry]120-lord henry , "[514-the old gentleman] said [the old gentleman]514-the old gentleman , " what brings [you]120-lord henry out so early ? [I]514-the old gentleman thought [[you]120-lord henry dandies]2180-you dandies never got up till two , and were not visible till five . "[514-the old gentleman]

" Pure family affection , [I]489-his uncle assure [you]120-lord henry , [Uncle George]139-uncle george . [I]489-his uncle want to get something out of [you]120-lord henry . "[489-his uncle]

" Money , [I]136-lord fermor suppose , "[136-lord fermor] said [Lord Fermor]136-lord fermor , making a wry face . " Well , sit down and tell [me]136-lord fermor all about it . [Young people]2181-young people , nowadays , imagine that money is everything . "[136-lord fermor]

" Yes , "[120-lord henry] murmured [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , settling [his]120-lord henry button - hole in [his]120-lord henry coat ; " and when [they]2181-young people grow older [they]2181-young people know it . But [I]120-lord henry don t want money . It is only people who pay [their]2181-young people bills who want that , [Uncle George]139-uncle george , and [I]120-lord henry never pay [mine]120-lord henry . Credit is the capital of [a younger son]2182-a younger son , and [one]381-one lives charmingly upon it . Besides , [I]120-lord henry always deal with [Dartmoor s tradesmen]2184-dartmoor s tradesmen , and consequently [they]2184-dartmoor s tradesmen never bother [me]120-lord henry . What [I]120-lord henry want is information : not useful information , of course ; useless information . "[120-lord henry]

" Well , [I]136-lord fermor can tell [you]120-lord henry anything that is in an English Blue Book , [Harry]120-lord henry , although [those fellows]2185-those fellows nowadays write a lot of nonsense . When [I]136-lord fermor was in [the Diplomatic]14-the diplomatic , things were much better . But [I]136-lord fermor hear [they]14-the diplomatic let [them]14-the diplomatic in now by examination . What can [you]120-lord henry expect ? Examinations , [sir]2063-sir , are pure humbug from beginning to end . If [a man]380-a man is [a gentleman]504-a gentleman , [he]380-a man knows quite enough , and if [he]380-a man is not [a gentleman]504-a gentleman , whatever [he]380-a man knows is bad for [him]380-a man . "[136-lord fermor]

" [Mr. Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray does not belong to Blue Books , [Uncle George]139-uncle george , "[120-lord henry] said [Lord Henry]120-lord henry languidly .

" [Mr. Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray ? Who is [he]117-dorian gray ? "[136-lord fermor] asked [Lord Fermor]136-lord fermor , knitting [his]136-lord fermor bushy white eyebrows .

" That is what [I]120-lord henry have come to learn , [Uncle George]139-uncle george . Or rather , [I]120-lord henry know who [he]117-dorian gray is . [He]117-dorian gray is [the last Lord Kelso s grandson]2190-the last lord kelso s grandson . [[His]117-dorian gray mother]2191-his mother was [a Devereux]2192-a devereux , [Lady Margaret Devereux]140-margaret devereux . [I]120-lord henry want [you]139-uncle george to tell [me]120-lord henry about [[his]117-dorian gray mother]2191-his mother . What was [she]2191-his mother like ? Whom did [she]2191-his mother marry ? [I]120-lord henry am very much interested in [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray at present . [I]120-lord henry have only just met [him]117-dorian gray . "[120-lord henry]

" [[Kelso]141-kelso s grandson]2194-kelso s grandson ! "[514-the old gentleman] echoed [the old gentleman]514-the old gentleman . " [[Kelso]141-kelso s grandson]2194-kelso s grandson ! ... Of course .... [I]514-the old gentleman knew [[his]117-dorian gray mother]2191-his mother intimately . [I]514-the old gentleman believe [I]514-the old gentleman was at [her]2191-his mother christening . [She]2191-his mother was [an extraordinarily beautiful girl]2197-an extraordinarily beautiful girl , [Margaret Devereux]140-margaret devereux , and made all [the men]2198-the men frantic by running away with [a penniless young fellow]2199-a penniless young fellow [a mere nobody]2200-a mere nobody , [sir]2063-sir , a subaltern in [a foot regiment , or something of that kind]2202-a foot regiment , or something of that kind . There was an ugly story about it . [They]2198-the men said [Kelso]141-kelso got [some rascally adventurer]2204-some rascally adventurer , [some Belgian brute]2205-some belgian brute , to insult [[his]141-kelso son - in - law]2206-his son - in - law in public paid [him]2204-some rascally adventurer , [sir]2063-sir , to do it , paid [him]2204-some rascally adventurer and that [the fellow]2208-the fellow spitted [[his]141-kelso man]2209-his man as if [he]2208-the fellow had been a pigeon . [He]141-kelso brought [[his]141-kelso daughter]2211-his daughter back with [him]141-kelso , [I]514-the old gentleman was told , and [she]2211-his daughter never spoke to [him]141-kelso again . " [Margaret Devereux]140-margaret devereux was one of the loveliest creatures [I]516-the old man ever saw , [Harry]120-lord henry . " At [Aunt Agatha]133-aunt agatha s. [I]120-lord henry have asked [myself]120-lord henry and [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray . [He]117-dorian gray is [her]133-aunt agatha latest _ prot g _ . "[120-lord henry]

"[120-lord henry]

" All right , [Uncle George]139-uncle george , [I]120-lord henry ll tell [her]133-aunt agatha , but it won t have any effect . [Philanthropic people]2255-philanthropic people lose all sense of humanity . It is [their]2255-philanthropic people distinguishing characteristic . "[120-lord henry]

[The old gentleman]514-the old gentleman growled approvingly and rang the bell for [[his]514-the old gentleman servant]422-his servant . [Lord Henry]120-lord henry passed up [the low arcade]522-the low arcade into [Burlington Street]19-burlington street and turned [his]120-lord henry steps in the direction of [Berkeley Square]20-berkeley square .

So that was the story of [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray s parentage . Crudely as it had been told to [him]120-lord henry , it had yet stirred [him]120-lord henry by its suggestion of a strange , almost modern romance . [A beautiful woman]523-a beautiful woman risking everything for a mad passion . A few wild weeks of happiness cut short by a hideous , treacherous crime . Months of voiceless agony , and then [a child born in pain]524-a child born in pain . [The mother]525-the mother snatched away by death , [the boy]2227-the boy left to solitude and the tyranny of [an old and loveless man]527-an old and loveless man . Yes ; it was an interesting background . It posed [the lad]427-the lad , made [him]427-the lad more perfect , as it were . Behind every exquisite thing that existed , there was something tragic . [Worlds]146-worlds had to be in travail , that the meanest flower might blow .... And how charming [he]427-the lad had been at dinner the night before , as with startled eyes and lips parted in frightened pleasure [he]427-the lad had sat opposite to [him]427-the lad at [the club]2210-the club , the red candleshades staining to a richer rose the wakening wonder of [his]427-the lad face . Talking to [him]427-the lad was like playing upon an exquisite violin . [He]427-the lad answered to every touch and thrill of the bow .... There was something terribly enthralling in the exercise of influence . No other activity was like it . To project one s soul into some gracious form , and let it tarry there for a moment ; to hear [one]381-one [s]381-one own intellectual views echoed back to one with all the added music of passion and youth ; to convey one s temperament into another as though it were a subtle fluid or a strange perfume : there was a real joy in that perhaps the most satisfying joy left to [us]531-us in an age so limited and vulgar as [our]531-us own , an age grossly carnal in its pleasures , and grossly common in its aims .... [He]427-the lad was [a marvellous type]532-a marvellous type , too , [this lad]2031-this lad , whom by so curious a chance [he]427-the lad had met in [[Basil]121-basil s studio]534-basil s studio , or could be fashioned into a marvellous type , at any rate . Grace was [his]427-the lad , and the white purity of boyhood , and beauty such as old Greek marbles kept for [us]531-us . There was nothing that [one]381-one could not do with [him]427-the lad . [He]427-the lad could be made [a Titan]536-a titan or a toy . What a pity it was that such beauty was destined to fade ! ... And [Basil]121-basil ? From a psychological point of view , how interesting [he]121-basil was ! The new manner in art , the fresh mode of looking at life , suggested so strangely by the merely visible presence of [one who was unconscious of it all]537-one who was unconscious of it all ; the silent spirit that dwelt in [dim woodland]538-dim woodland , and walked unseen in [open field]539-open field , suddenly showing [herself]537-one who was unconscious of it all , Dryadlike and not afraid , because in [his]121-basil soul who sought for [her]537-one who was unconscious of it all there had been wakened that wonderful vision to which alone are wonderful things revealed ; the mere shapes and patterns of things becoming , as it were , refined , and gaining a kind of symbolical value , as though they were themselves patterns of some other and more perfect form whose shadow [they]540-they made real : how strange it all was ! [He]121-basil remembered something like it in history . Was it not [Plato]147-plato , [that artist in thought]541-that artist in thought , who had first analyzed it ? Was it not [Buonarotti]148-buonarotti who had carved it in the coloured marbles of a sonnet - sequence ? But in [our]531-us own century it was strange .... Yes ; [he]121-basil would try to be to [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray what , without knowing it , [the lad]427-the lad was to [the painter who had fashioned the wonderful portrait]543-the painter who had fashioned the wonderful portrait . [He]121-basil would seek to dominate [him]121-basil had already , indeed , half done so . [He]121-basil would make that wonderful spirit [his]121-basil own . There was something fascinating in [this son of love and death]544-this son of love and death .

Suddenly [he]121-basil stopped and glanced up at [the houses]545-the houses . [He]121-basil found that [he]121-basil had passed [[his]121-basil aunt]418-his aunt s some distance , and , smiling to [himself]121-basil , turned back . When [he]121-basil entered [the somewhat sombre hall]547-the somewhat sombre hall , [the butler]419-the butler told [him]121-basil that [they]549-they had gone in to lunch . [He]121-basil gave one of [the footmen]550-the footmen [his]121-basil hat and stick and passed into [the dining - room]551-the dining - room .

" Late as usual , [Harry]120-lord henry , "[418-his aunt] cried [[his]121-basil aunt]418-his aunt , shaking [her]418-his aunt head at [him]121-basil .

[He]121-basil invented a facile excuse , and having taken the vacant seat next to [her]418-his aunt , looked round to see [who was there]553-who was there . [Dorian]554-dorian bowed to [him]121-basil shyly from the end of the table , a flush of pleasure stealing into [his]121-basil cheek . Opposite was [the Duchess of [Harley]21-harley]555-the duchess of harley , [a lady of admirable good - nature and good temper]556-a lady of admirable good - nature and good temper , much liked by [every one who knew [her]555-the duchess of harley]557-every one who knew her , and of those ample architectural proportions that in [women who are not duchesses]558-women who are not duchesses are described by [contemporary historians]559-contemporary historians as stoutness . Next to [her]418-his aunt sat , on [her]418-his aunt right , [Sir Thomas Burdon]149-sir thomas , [a Radical member of Parliament , who followed [[his]149-sir thomas leader]561-his leader in public life and in private life followed [the best cooks]562-the best cooks , dining with [the Tories]506-the tories and thinking with [the Liberals]150-the liberals , in accordance with a wise and well - known rule]560-a radical member of parliament , who followed his leader in public life and in private life followed the best cooks , dining with the tories and thinking with the liberals , in accordance with a wise and well - known rule . The post on [her]418-his aunt left was occupied by [Mr. Erskine of Treadley]151-mr. erskine , [an old gentleman of considerable charm and culture]564-an old gentleman of considerable charm and culture , who had fallen , however , into bad habits of silence , having , as [he]151-mr. erskine explained once to [Lady Agatha]131-lady agatha , said everything that [he]151-mr. erskine had to say before [he]151-mr. erskine was thirty . [[His]151-mr. erskine own neighbour]565-his own neighbour was [Mrs. Vandeleur]152-mrs. vandeleur , [one of [[his]151-mr. erskine aunt s oldest friends]567-his aunt s oldest friends , [a perfect saint amongst [women]2058-women]568-a perfect saint amongst women , but so dreadfully dowdy that [she]152-mrs. vandeleur reminded one of a badly bound hymn - book . Fortunately for [him]151-mr. erskine [she]418-his aunt had on the other side [Lord Faudel]153-lord faudel , [a most intelligent middle - aged mediocrity]570-a most intelligent middle - aged mediocrity , as bald as a ministerial statement in [the House of Commons]571-the house of commons , with whom [she]418-his aunt was conversing in that intensely earnest manner which is the one unpardonable error , as [he]151-mr. erskine remarked once [himself]151-mr. erskine , that [all really good people]572-all really good people fall into , and from which none of [them]572-all really good people ever quite escape]566-one of his aunt s oldest friends , a perfect saint amongst women , but so dreadfully dowdy that she reminded one of a badly bound hymn - book . fortunately for him she had on the other side lord faudel , a most intelligent middle - aged mediocrity , as bald as a ministerial statement in the house of commons , with whom she was conversing in that intensely earnest manner which is the one unpardonable error , as he remarked once himself , that all really good people fall into , and from which none of them ever quite escape .

" [We]2256-we are talking about poor Dartmoor , [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , "[573-the duchess] cried [the duchess]573-the duchess , nodding pleasantly to [him]151-mr. erskine across the table . " Do [you]151-mr. erskine think [he]151-mr. erskine will really marry [this fascinating young person]2257-this fascinating young person ? "[573-the duchess]

" [I]572-all really good people believe [she]418-his aunt has made up [her]418-his aunt mind to propose to [him]151-mr. erskine , [Duchess]154-duchess . "[572-all really good people]

" Yes , "[120-lord henry] [he]120-lord henry continued , " that is one of the great secrets of life . Nowadays [most people]2291-most people die of a sort of creeping common sense , and discover when it is too late that the only things [one]381-one never regrets are one s mistakes . "[120-lord henry]

A laugh ran round the table .

[He]120-lord henry played with the idea and grew wilful ; tossed it into the air and transformed it ; let [it]585-it escape and recaptured it ; made it iridescent with fancy and winged it with paradox . The praise of folly , as [he]120-lord henry went on , soared into a philosophy , and [philosophy]586-philosophy [herself]586-philosophy became young , and catching the mad music of pleasure , wearing , one might fancy , [her]586-philosophy wine - stained robe and wreath of ivy , danced like a Bacchante over the hills of life , and mocked [the slow Silenus]157-the slow silenus for being sober . [Facts]158-facts fled before [her]586-philosophy like frightened forest things . [Her]586-philosophy white feet trod the huge press at which [wise Omar]159-wise omar sits , till the seething grape - juice rose round [her]586-philosophy bare limbs in waves of purple bubbles , or crawled in red foam over the vat s black , dripping , sloping sides . It was an extraordinary improvisation . [He]120-lord henry felt that the eyes of [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray were fixed on [him]120-lord henry , and the consciousness that amongst [[his]120-lord henry audience]587-his audience there was one whose temperament [he]120-lord henry wished to fascinate seemed to give [his]120-lord henry wit keenness and to lend colour to [his]120-lord henry imagination . [He]120-lord henry was brilliant , fantastic , irresponsible . [He]120-lord henry charmed [[his]120-lord henry listeners]577-his listeners out of [themselves]577-his listeners , and [they]577-his listeners followed [his]120-lord henry pipe , laughing . [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray never took [his]117-dorian gray gaze off [him]120-lord henry , but sat like one under a spell , smiles chasing each other over [his]120-lord henry lips and wonder growing grave in [his]120-lord henry darkening eyes .

At last , liveried in the costume of the age , reality entered [the room]386-the room in the shape of [a servant]590-a servant to tell [the duchess]573-the duchess that [[her]573-the duchess carriage]592-her carriage was waiting . [She]573-the duchess wrung [her]573-the duchess hands in mock despair . " How annoying ! "[573-the duchess] [she]573-the duchess cried . " [I]573-the duchess must go . [I]573-the duchess have to call for [[my]573-the duchess husband]2293-my husband at [the club]2210-the club , to take [him]2293-my husband to some absurd meeting at [Willis s Rooms]22-willis s rooms , where [he]2293-my husband is going to be in the chair . If [I]573-the duchess am late [he]2293-my husband is sure to be furious , and [I]573-the duchess couldn t have a scene in [this bonnet]2295-this bonnet . It is far too fragile . A harsh word would ruin it . No , [I]573-the duchess must go , dear [Agatha]131-lady agatha . " For [you]131-lady agatha [I]120-lord henry would throw over [anybody]1955-anybody , [Duchess]2298-duchess , "[120-lord henry] said [Lord Henry]120-lord henry with a bow .

CHAPTER IV .

One afternoon , a month later , [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray was reclining in a luxurious arm - chair , in [the little library of [Lord Henry]120-lord henry s house in [Mayfair]24-mayfair]597-the little library of lord henry s house in mayfair . [It]597-the little library of lord henry s house in mayfair was , in [its]597-the little library of lord henry s house in mayfair way , [a very charming room]598-a very charming room , with [its]597-the little library of lord henry s house in mayfair high panelled wainscoting of olive - stained oak , [its]597-the little library of lord henry s house in mayfair cream - coloured frieze and ceiling of raised plasterwork , and [its]597-the little library of lord henry s house in mayfair brickdust felt carpet strewn with silk , long - fringed Persian rugs . On a tiny satinwood table stood a statuette by [Clodion]161-clodion , and beside it lay a copy of [Les Cent Nouvelles]25-les cent nouvelles , bound for [Margaret of Valois]162-margaret of valois by [Clovis Eve]145-eve and powdered with the gilt daisies that [Queen]599-queen had selected for [her]599-queen device . Some large blue china jars and parrot - tulips were ranged on the mantelshelf , and through the small leaded panes of the window streamed the apricot - coloured light of a summer day in [London]2-london .

[Lord Henry]120-lord henry had not yet come in . [He]120-lord henry was always late on principle , [his]120-lord henry principle being that punctuality is the thief of time . So [the lad]427-the lad was looking rather sulky , as with listless fingers [he]427-the lad turned over the pages of an elaborately illustrated edition of [Manon Lescaut]163-manon lescaut that [he]427-the lad had found in one of the book - cases . The formal monotonous ticking of the Louis Quatorze clock annoyed [him]427-the lad . Once or twice [he]427-the lad thought of going away .

At last [he]427-the lad heard a step outside , and the door opened . " How late [you]2311-you are , [Harry]120-lord henry ! "[427-the lad] [he]427-the lad murmured .

" [I]427-the lad am afraid it is not [Harry]120-lord henry , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray , "[427-the lad] answered a shrill voice .

[He]427-the lad glanced quickly round and rose to [his]427-the lad feet . " [I]427-the lad beg [your]2311-you pardon . [I]427-the lad thought "[427-the lad]

" [You]2311-you thought it was [[my]601-i husband]2293-my husband . It is only [[his]2293-my husband wife]2313-his wife . [You]2311-you must let [me]601-i introduce [myself]601-i . [I]601-i know [you]2311-you quite well by [your]2311-you photographs . [I]601-i think [[my]601-i husband]2293-my husband has got seventeen of them . "[601-i]

" Not seventeen , [Lady Henry]164-harry ? "[427-the lad]

" Well , eighteen , then . And [I]601-i saw [you]2311-you with [him]2293-my husband the other night at the opera . "[601-i] [She]601-i laughed nervously as [she]601-i spoke , and watched [him]602-him with [her]601-i vague forget - [me]0-perles ruisselant - not eyes . [She]601-i was [a curious woman , whose dresses always looked as if they had been designed in a rage and put on in a tempest]603-a curious woman , whose dresses always looked as if they had been designed in a rage and put on in a tempest . [She]601-i was usually in love with [somebody]604-somebody , and , as [her]601-i passion was never returned , [she]601-i had kept all [her]601-i illusions . [She]601-i tried to look picturesque , but only succeeded in being untidy . [Her]601-i name was [Victoria]165-victoria , and [she]601-i had a perfect mania for going to [church]605-church .

" That was at [Lohengrin]26-lohengrin , [Lady Henry]164-harry , [I]601-i think ? "[601-i]

" Yes ; it was at dear [Lohengrin]26-lohengrin . [I]601-i like [Wagner]166-wagner s music better than [anybody]1955-anybody s. It is so loud that [one]381-one can talk the whole time without [other people]2010-other people hearing what [one]381-one says . That is a great advantage , don t [you]164-harry think so , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray ? "[601-i]

The same nervous staccato laugh broke from [her]601-i thin lips , and [her]601-i fingers began to play with a long tortoise - shell paper - knife .

[Dorian]117-dorian gray smiled and shook [his]117-dorian gray head : " [I]117-dorian gray am afraid [I]117-dorian gray don t think so , [Lady Henry]164-harry . [I]117-dorian gray never talk during music at least , during good music . If one hears bad music , it is one s duty to drown it in conversation . "[117-dorian gray]

" Ah ! that is one of [Harry]164-harry s views , isn t it , [Mr. Gray]117-dorian gray ? [I]601-i always hear [Harry]164-harry s views from [[his]601-i friends]390-his friends . It is the only way [I]601-i get to know of [them]390-his friends . But [you]164-harry must not think [I]601-i don t like good music . [I]601-i adore it , but [I]601-i am afraid of it . It makes [me]601-i too romantic . [I]601-i have simply worshipped [pianists]2320-pianists two at a time , sometimes , [Harry]164-harry tells [me]601-i . [I]601-i don t know what it is about [them]2320-pianists . Perhaps it is that [they]2320-pianists are [foreigners]2321-foreigners . [They]2320-pianists all are , ain t [they]2320-pianists ? Even [those that are born in [England]5-england]2322-those that are born in england become [foreigners]2321-foreigners after a time , don t [they]2320-pianists ? And [her]2406-this girl voice [I]120-lord henry never heard such a voice . It was very low at first , with deep mellow notes that seemed to fall singly upon one s ear . Then it became a little louder , and sounded like a flute or a distant hautboy . In the garden - scene it had all the tremulous ecstasy that one hears just before dawn when nightingales are singing . There were moments , later on , when it had the wild passion of violins . [You]120-lord henry know how a voice can stir one . [Your]120-lord henry voice and the voice of [Sibyl Vane]168-sibyl are two things that [I]120-lord henry shall never forget . "[117-dorian gray] [He]609-he was walking up and down [the room]386-the room as [he]609-he spoke . Hectic spots of red burned on [his]609-he cheeks . [He]609-he was terribly excited .

" And what do [you]120-lord henry propose to do ? "[120-lord henry] said [Lord Henry]120-lord henry at last .

" [Dear Basil]179-dear basil ! [I]120-lord henry have not laid eyes on [him]121-basil for a week . [Lord Henry]120-lord henry smiled . " [People]1933-people are very fond of giving away what [they]1933-people need most [themselves]1933-people . It is what [I]120-lord henry call the depth of generosity . "[120-lord henry]

" Oh , [Basil]121-basil is the best of [fellows]2478-fellows , but [he]121-basil seems to [me]120-lord henry to be just a bit of [a Philistine]2479-a philistine . " [Basil]121-basil , [[my]120-lord henry dear boy]2346-my dear boy , puts everything that is charming in [him]121-basil into [his]121-basil work . The consequence is that [he]121-basil has nothing left for life but [his]121-basil prejudices , [his]121-basil principles , and [his]121-basil common sense . [The only artists [I]120-lord henry have ever known who are personally delightful]2481-the only artists i have ever known who are personally delightful are [bad artists]2482-bad artists . [Good artists]2483-good artists exist simply in what [they]2483-good artists make , and consequently are perfectly uninteresting in what [they]2483-good artists are . [A great poet]2484-a great poet , [a really great poet]2485-a really great poet , is the most unpoetical of [all creatures]2486-all creatures . But [inferior poets]2487-inferior poets are absolutely fascinating . The worse [their]2487-inferior poets rhymes are , the more picturesque [they]2487-inferior poets look . The mere fact of having published a book of [second - rate sonnets]2488-second - rate sonnets makes [a man]380-a man quite irresistible . [He]380-a man lives the poetry that [he]380-a man can not write . [The others]2490-the others write the poetry that [they]2490-the others dare not realize . "[120-lord henry]

" [I]117-dorian gray wonder is that really so , [Harry]120-lord henry ?
