[He]117-dorian gray wondered if [he]117-dorian gray had met [the men in [the hall]1025-the hall as [they]1062-the men in the hall as they were leaving the house were leaving [the house]425-the house]1062-the men in the hall as they were leaving the house and had wormed out of [them]1062-the men in the hall as they were leaving the house what [they]1062-the men in the hall as they were leaving the house had been doing . [He]117-dorian gray would be sure to miss the picture had no doubt missed it already , while [he]117-dorian gray had been laying the tea - things . The screen had not been set back , and a blank space was visible on the wall . Perhaps some night [he]117-dorian gray might find [him]117-dorian gray creeping [upstairs]676-upstairs and trying to force the door of [the room]386-the room . It was a horrible thing to have [a spy]1067-a spy in [one s house]1068-one s house . [He]117-dorian gray had heard of [rich men who had been blackmailed all [their]1069-rich men who had been blackmailed all their lives lives]1069-rich men who had been blackmailed all their lives by [some servant who had read a letter , or overheard a conversation]1070-some servant who had read a letter , or overheard a conversation , or picked up a card with an address , or found beneath a pillow a withered flower or a shred of crumpled lace .

[He]117-dorian gray sighed , and having poured [himself]117-dorian gray out some tea , opened [Lord Henry]120-lord henry s note . It was simply to say that [he]120-lord henry sent [him]117-dorian gray round the evening paper , and a book that might interest [him]117-dorian gray , and that [he]117-dorian gray would be at [the club]2210-the club at eight - fifteen . [He]117-dorian gray opened _ [The St. James s _]1072-the st. james s _ languidly , and looked through it . A red pencil - mark on the fifth page caught [his]117-dorian gray eye . It drew attention to the following paragraph :

INQUEST ON [AN ACTRESS]2342-an actress . An inquest was held this morning at [the Bell Tavern]47-the bell tavern , [Hoxton Road]48-hoxton road , by [Mr. Danby]220-mr. danby , [the District Coroner]1074-the district coroner , on the body of [Sibyl Vane]168-sibyl , [a young actress recently engaged at [the Royal Theatre]1076-the royal theatre , [Holborn]49-holborn]1075-a young actress recently engaged at the royal theatre , holborn . A verdict of death by misadventure was returned . Considerable sympathy was expressed for [the mother of [the deceased]1078-the deceased , who was greatly affected during the giving of [her]1079-her own evidence , and that of [Dr. Birrell]221-dr. birrell , who had made the post - mortem examination of [the deceased]1078-the deceased]1077-the mother of the deceased , who was greatly affected during the giving of her own evidence , and that of dr. birrell , who had made the post - mortem examination of the deceased .

[He]117-dorian gray frowned , and tearing the paper in two , went across [the room]386-the room and flung the pieces away . How ugly it all was ! And how horribly real ugliness made things ! [He]117-dorian gray felt a little annoyed with [Lord Henry]120-lord henry for having sent [him]117-dorian gray the report . And it was certainly stupid of [him]117-dorian gray to have marked it with red pencil . [Victor]195-victor might have read it . [The man]2023-the man knew more than enough English for that .

Perhaps [he]2023-the man had read it and had begun to suspect something . And , yet , what did it matter ? What had [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray to do with [Sibyl Vane]168-sibyl s death ? There was nothing to fear . [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray had not killed [her]168-sibyl .

[His]117-dorian gray eye fell on the yellow book that [Lord Henry]120-lord henry had sent [him]117-dorian gray . What was it , [he]117-dorian gray wondered . [He]117-dorian gray went towards the little , pearl - coloured octagonal stand that had always looked to [him]117-dorian gray like the work of some strange Egyptian bees that wrought in silver , and taking up the volume , flung [himself]117-dorian gray into an arm - chair and began to turn over the leaves . After a few minutes [he]117-dorian gray became absorbed . It was the strangest book that [he]117-dorian gray had ever read . It seemed to [him]117-dorian gray that in exquisite raiment , and to the delicate sound of flutes , the sins of [the world]1908-the world were passing in dumb show before [him]117-dorian gray . Things that [he]117-dorian gray had dimly dreamed of were suddenly made real to [him]117-dorian gray . Things of which [he]117-dorian gray had never dreamed were gradually revealed .

It was a novel without a plot and with only [one character]1084-one character , being , indeed , simply a psychological study of [a certain young Parisian who spent [his]1085-a certain young parisian who spent his life trying to realize in the nineteenth century all the passions and modes of thought that belonged to every century except his own life trying to realize in the nineteenth century all the passions and modes of thought that belonged to every century except [his]1085-a certain young parisian who spent his life trying to realize in the nineteenth century all the passions and modes of thought that belonged to every century except his own own]1085-a certain young parisian who spent his life trying to realize in the nineteenth century all the passions and modes of thought that belonged to every century except his own , and to sum up , as it were , in [himself]1085-a certain young parisian who spent his life trying to realize in the nineteenth century all the passions and modes of thought that belonged to every century except his own the various moods through which [the world - spirit]1086-the world - spirit had ever passed , loving for [their]1087-their mere artificiality those renunciations that [men]2041-men have unwisely called virtue , as much as those natural rebellions that [wise men]1089-wise men still call sin . The style in which it was written was that curious jewelled style , vivid and obscure at once , full of _ argot _ and of archaisms , of technical expressions and of elaborate paraphrases , that characterizes the work of [some of [the finest artists of the French school of _ Symbolistes _]1091-the finest artists of the french school of _ symbolistes _]1090-some of the finest artists of the french school of _ symbolistes _ . There were in it metaphors as monstrous as orchids and as subtle in colour . The life of the senses was described in the terms of mystical philosophy . [One]381-one hardly knew at times whether [one]381-one was reading the spiritual ecstasies of [some medi val saint]1093-some medi val saint or the morbid confessions of [a modern sinner]1094-a modern sinner . It was a poisonous book . The heavy odour of incense seemed to cling about its pages and to trouble the brain . The mere cadence of the sentences , the subtle monotony of their music , so full as it was of complex refrains and movements elaborately repeated , produced in the mind of [the lad]427-the lad , as [he]117-dorian gray passed from chapter to chapter , a form of reverie , a malady of dreaming , that made [him]117-dorian gray unconscious of the falling day and creeping shadows .

Cloudless , and pierced by one solitary star , a copper - green sky gleamed through the windows . [He]117-dorian gray read on by its wan light till [he]117-dorian gray could read no more . Then , after [[his]117-dorian gray valet]509-his valet had reminded [him]117-dorian gray several times of the lateness of the hour , [he]117-dorian gray got up , and going into [the next room]1097-the next room , placed the book on the little Florentine table that always stood at [his]117-dorian gray bedside and began to dress for dinner .

It was almost nine o clock before [he]117-dorian gray reached [the club]2210-the club , where [he]117-dorian gray found [Lord Henry]120-lord henry sitting alone , in [the morning - room]1099-the morning - room , looking very much bored .

" [I]117-dorian gray am so sorry , [Harry]120-lord henry , "[117-dorian gray] [he]117-dorian gray cried , " but really it is entirely [your]120-lord henry fault . That book [you]120-lord henry sent [me]117-dorian gray so fascinated [me]117-dorian gray that [I]117-dorian gray forgot how the time was going . "[117-dorian gray]

" Yes , [I]1100-his host thought [you]1100-his host would like it , "[1100-his host] replied [[his]117-dorian gray host]1100-his host , rising from [his]1100-his host chair .

" [I]117-dorian gray didn t say [I]117-dorian gray liked it , [Harry]120-lord henry . [I]117-dorian gray said it fascinated [me]117-dorian gray . There is a great difference . "[117-dorian gray]

" Ah , [you]1100-his host have discovered that ? "[120-lord henry] murmured [Lord Henry]120-lord henry . And [they]1101-they passed into [the dining - room]551-the dining - room .

CHAPTER XI .

For years , [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray could not free [himself]117-dorian gray from the influence of this book . Or perhaps it would be more accurate to say that [he]117-dorian gray never sought to free [himself]117-dorian gray from it . [He]117-dorian gray procured from [Paris]13-paris no less than nine large - paper copies of the first edition , and had them bound in different colours , so that they might suit [his]117-dorian gray various moods and the changing fancies of a nature over which [he]117-dorian gray seemed , at times , to have almost entirely lost control . [The hero]1103-the hero , [the wonderful young Parisian in whom the romantic and the scientific temperaments were so strangely blended]1104-the wonderful young parisian in whom the romantic and the scientific temperaments were so strangely blended , became to [him]117-dorian gray a kind of prefiguring type of [himself]117-dorian gray . And , indeed , the whole book seemed to [him]117-dorian gray to contain the story of [his]117-dorian gray own life , written before [he]117-dorian gray had lived it .

In one point [he]117-dorian gray was more fortunate than [the novel s fantastic hero]1105-the novel s fantastic hero . [He]117-dorian gray never knew never , indeed , had any cause to know that somewhat grotesque dread of mirrors , and polished metal surfaces , and still water which came upon [the young Parisian]1106-the young parisian so early in [his]117-dorian gray life , and was occasioned by the sudden decay of a beau that had once , apparently , been so remarkable . It was with an almost cruel joy and perhaps in nearly every joy , as certainly in every pleasure , cruelty has its place that [he]117-dorian gray used to read the latter part of the book , with its really tragic , if somewhat overemphasized , account of the sorrow and despair of one who had [himself]117-dorian gray lost what in others , and [the world]1908-the world , [he]117-dorian gray had most dearly valued .

For the wonderful beauty that had so fascinated [Basil Hallward]121-basil , and [many others besides [him]117-dorian gray]1108-many others besides him , seemed never to leave [him]117-dorian gray . Even [those who had heard the most evil things against [him]117-dorian gray and from time to time strange rumours about [his]117-dorian gray mode of life]1109-those who had heard the most evil things against him and from time to time strange rumours about his mode of life crept through [London]2-london and became the chatter of [the clubs]1110-the clubs could not believe anything to [his]117-dorian gray dishonour when [they]1110-the clubs saw [him]117-dorian gray . [He]117-dorian gray had always the look of one who had kept [himself]117-dorian gray unspotted from [the world]1908-the world . [Men who talked grossly]1112-men who talked grossly became silent when [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray entered [the room]386-the room . There was something in the purity of [his]117-dorian gray face that rebuked [them]1112-men who talked grossly . [His]117-dorian gray mere presence seemed to recall to [them]1112-men who talked grossly the memory of the innocence that [they]1112-men who talked grossly had tarnished . [They]1112-men who talked grossly wondered how one so charming and graceful as [he]117-dorian gray was could have escaped the stain of an age that was at once sordid and sensual .

Often , on returning [home]2087-home from one of those mysterious and prolonged absences that gave rise to such strange conjecture among [those who were [[his]117-dorian gray friends]390-his friends]1115-those who were his friends , or thought that [they]1115-those who were his friends were so , [he]117-dorian gray [himself]117-dorian gray would creep [upstairs]676-upstairs to [the locked room]1118-the locked room , open the door with the key that never left [him]117-dorian gray now , and stand , with a mirror , in front of the portrait that [Basil Hallward]121-basil had painted of [him]117-dorian gray , looking now at the evil and aging face on the canvas , and now at the fair young face that laughed back at [him]117-dorian gray from the polished glass . The very sharpness of the contrast used to quicken [his]117-dorian gray sense of pleasure . [He]117-dorian gray grew more and more enamoured of [his]117-dorian gray own beauty , more and more interested in the corruption of [his]117-dorian gray own soul . [He]117-dorian gray would examine with minute care , and sometimes with a monstrous and terrible delight , the hideous lines that seared the wrinkling forehead or crawled around the heavy sensual mouth , wondering sometimes which were the more horrible , the signs of sin or the signs of age . [He]117-dorian gray would place [his]117-dorian gray white hands beside the coarse bloated hands of the picture , and smile . [He]117-dorian gray mocked the misshapen body and the failing limbs .

There were moments , indeed , at night , when , lying sleepless in [[his]117-dorian gray own delicately scented chamber]1119-his own delicately scented chamber , or in [the sordid room of [the little ill - famed tavern near [the docks]1122-the docks which , under an assumed name and in disguise , it was [his]117-dorian gray habit to frequent]1121-the little ill - famed tavern near the docks which , under an assumed name and in disguise , it was his habit to frequent]1120-the sordid room of the little ill - famed tavern near the docks which , under an assumed name and in disguise , it was his habit to frequent , [he]117-dorian gray would think of the ruin [he]117-dorian gray had brought upon [his]117-dorian gray soul with a pity that was all the more poignant because it was purely selfish . But moments such as these were rare . That curiosity about life which [Lord Henry]120-lord henry had first stirred in [him]117-dorian gray , as [they]1123-they sat together in [the garden of [[their]1123-they friend]1125-their friend]1124-the garden of their friend , seemed to increase with gratification . The more [he]117-dorian gray knew , the more [he]117-dorian gray desired to know . [He]117-dorian gray had mad hungers that grew more ravenous as [he]117-dorian gray fed [them]1126-them .

Yet [he]117-dorian gray was not really reckless , at any rate in [his]117-dorian gray relations to [society]1127-society . Once or twice every month during the winter , and on each Wednesday evening while the season lasted , [he]117-dorian gray would throw open to [the world]1908-the world [[his]117-dorian gray beautiful house]1129-his beautiful house and have [the most celebrated musicians of the day to charm [[his]117-dorian gray guests]1131-his guests with the wonders of [their]1131-his guests art]1130-the most celebrated musicians of the day to charm his guests with the wonders of their art . [[His]117-dorian gray little dinners]1132-his little dinners , in the settling of which [Lord Henry]120-lord henry always assisted [him]117-dorian gray , were noted as much for the careful selection and placing of [those invited]1133-those invited , as for the exquisite taste shown in the decoration of the table , with its subtle symphonic arrangements of exotic flowers , and embroidered cloths , and antique plate of gold and silver . Indeed , there were many , especially among [the very young men]1134-the very young men , who saw , or fancied that [they]1134-the very young men saw , in [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray the true realization of a type of which [they]1134-the very young men had often dreamed in [Eton]50-eton or [Oxford]4-oxford days , a type that was to combine something of the real culture of [the scholar]1135-the scholar with all the grace and distinction and perfect manner of [a citizen of [the world]1908-the world]1136-a citizen of the world . To [them]1134-the very young men [he]117-dorian gray seemed to be of the company of those whom [Dante]222-dante describes as having sought to " make [themselves]1134-the very young men [perfect by the worship of beauty]2998-perfect by the worship of beauty . "[117-dorian gray] Like [Gautier]208-gautier , [he]117-dorian gray was one for whom " [the visible world]2999-the visible world existed . "[117-dorian gray]

And , certainly , to [him]117-dorian gray life itself was the first , the greatest , of the arts , and for it all the other arts seemed to be but a preparation . Fashion , by which what is really fantastic becomes for a moment universal , and dandyism , which , in its own way , is an attempt to assert the absolute modernity of beauty , had , of course , [their]1134-the very young men fascination for [him]117-dorian gray . [His]117-dorian gray mode of dressing , and the particular styles that from time to time [he]117-dorian gray affected , had their marked influence on [the young exquisites of the Mayfair balls]1138-the young exquisites of the mayfair balls and [Pall Mall club windows]1139-pall mall club windows , who copied [him]117-dorian gray in everything that [he]117-dorian gray did , and tried to reproduce the accidental charm of [his]117-dorian gray graceful , though to [him]117-dorian gray only half - serious , fopperies .

For , while [he]117-dorian gray was but too ready to accept the position that was almost immediately offered to [him]117-dorian gray on [his]117-dorian gray coming of age , and found , indeed , a subtle pleasure in the thought that [he]117-dorian gray might really become to the London of [his]117-dorian gray own day what to imperial [Neronian Rome]223-neronian rome [the author of the Satyricon]1140-the author of the satyricon once had been , yet in [his]117-dorian gray inmost heart [he]117-dorian gray desired to be something more than [a mere _ arbiter elegantiarum _]1141-a mere _ arbiter elegantiarum _ , to be consulted on the wearing of a jewel , or the knotting of a necktie , or the conduct of a cane . [He]117-dorian gray sought to elaborate some new scheme of life that would have its reasoned philosophy and its ordered principles , and find in the spiritualizing of the senses its highest realization .

The worship of the senses has often , and with much justice , been decried , [men]2041-men feeling a natural instinct of terror about passions and sensations that seem stronger than [themselves]2041-men , and that [they]2041-men are conscious of sharing with the less highly organized forms of existence . But it appeared to [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray that the true nature of the senses had never been understood , and that [they]2041-men had remained savage and animal merely because [the world]1908-the world had sought to starve [them]2041-men into submission or to kill [them]2041-men by pain , instead of aiming at making [them]2041-men elements of a new spirituality , of which a fine instinct for beauty was to be the dominant characteristic . As [he]117-dorian gray looked back upon [man]364-man moving through history , [he]117-dorian gray was haunted by a feeling of loss . So much had been surrendered ! and to such little purpose ! There had been mad wilful rejections , monstrous forms of self - torture and self - denial , whose origin was fear and whose result was a degradation infinitely more terrible than that fancied degradation from which , in [their]2041-men ignorance , [they]2041-men had sought to escape ; [Nature]190-nature , in [her]190-nature wonderful irony , driving out the anchorite to feed with the wild animals of [the desert]1145-the desert and giving to [the hermit]1146-the hermit the beasts of [the field]1147-the field as [[his]117-dorian gray companions]1148-his companions .

Yes : there was to be , as [Lord Henry]120-lord henry had prophesied , [a new Hedonism that was to recreate life and to save it from that harsh uncomely puritanism that is having , in [our]1150-we own day , its curious revival]1149-a new hedonism that was to recreate life and to save it from that harsh uncomely puritanism that is having , in our own day , its curious revival . [It]1149-a new hedonism that was to recreate life and to save it from that harsh uncomely puritanism that is having , in our own day , its curious revival was to have [its]1149-a new hedonism that was to recreate life and to save it from that harsh uncomely puritanism that is having , in our own day , its curious revival service of the intellect , certainly , yet it was never to accept any theory or system that would involve the sacrifice of any mode of passionate experience . [Its]1149-a new hedonism that was to recreate life and to save it from that harsh uncomely puritanism that is having , in our own day , its curious revival aim , indeed , was to be experience itself , and not the fruits of experience , sweet or bitter as they might be . Of the asceticism that deadens the senses , as of the vulgar profligacy that dulls [them]2041-men , it was to know nothing . But it was to teach [man]364-man to concentrate [himself]364-man upon the moments of a life that is itself but a moment .

There are [few of [us]1150-we who have not sometimes wakened before dawn , either after one of those dreamless nights that make [us]1150-we almost enamoured of death]1152-few of us who have not sometimes wakened before dawn , either after one of those dreamless nights that make us almost enamoured of death , or [one of those nights of horror and misshapen joy]1153-one of those nights of horror and misshapen joy , when through the chambers of the brain sweep phantoms more terrible than reality itself , and instinct with that vivid life that lurks in all grotesques , and that lends to Gothic art its enduring vitality , this art being , [one]381-one might fancy , especially the art of [those whose minds have been troubled with the malady of reverie]1155-those whose minds have been troubled with the malady of reverie . Gradually white fingers creep through the curtains , and they appear to tremble . In black fantastic shapes , dumb shadows crawl into the corners of [the room]386-the room and crouch there . Outside , there is the stirring of birds among the leaves , or the sound of [men]2041-men going forth to [their]2041-men work , or the sigh and sob of the wind coming down from [the hills]1158-the hills and wandering round [the silent house]1159-the silent house , as though it feared to wake [the sleepers]1160-the sleepers and yet must needs call forth sleep from [[her]1161-her purple cave]1162-her purple cave . Veil after veil of thin dusky gauze is lifted , and by degrees the forms and colours of things are restored to them , and [we]1150-we watch the dawn remaking [the world]1908-the world in its antique pattern . The wan mirrors get back their mimic life . The flameless tapers stand where [we]1150-we had left them , and beside them lies the half - cut book that [we]1150-we had been studying , or the wired flower that [we]1150-we had worn at the ball , or the letter that [we]1150-we had been afraid to read , or that [we]1150-we had read too often . Nothing seems to [us]1150-we changed . Out of the unreal shadows of the night comes back the real life that [we]1150-we had known . [We]1150-we have to resume it where [we]1150-we had left off , and there steals over [us]1150-we a terrible sense of the necessity for the continuance of energy in the same wearisome round of stereotyped habits , or a wild longing , it may be , that [our]1150-we eyelids might open some morning upon [a world that had been refashioned anew in the darkness]1164-a world that had been refashioned anew in the darkness for [our]1150-we pleasure , a world in which things would have fresh shapes and colours , and be changed , or have other secrets , a world in which the past would have little or no place , or survive , at any rate , in no conscious form of obligation or regret , the remembrance even of joy having its bitterness and the memories of pleasure [their]1165-their pain .

It was the creation of such worlds as these that seemed to [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray to be the true object , or amongst the true objects , of life ; and in [his]117-dorian gray search for sensations that would be at once new and delightful , and possess that element of strangeness that is so essential to romance , [he]117-dorian gray would often adopt certain modes of thought that [he]117-dorian gray knew to be really alien to [his]117-dorian gray nature , abandon [himself]117-dorian gray to [their]1166-their subtle influences , and then , having , as it were , caught [their]1166-their colour and satisfied [his]117-dorian gray intellectual curiosity , leave [them]1166-their with that curious indifference that is not incompatible with a real ardour of temperament , and that , indeed , according to [certain modern psychologists]1167-certain modern psychologists , is often a condition of it .

It was rumoured of [him]117-dorian gray once that [he]117-dorian gray was about to join [the Roman Catholic communion]1168-the roman catholic communion , and certainly the Roman ritual had always a great attraction for [him]117-dorian gray . The daily sacrifice , more awful really than all the sacrifices of [the antique world]1169-the antique world , stirred [him]117-dorian gray as much by its superb rejection of the evidence of the senses as by the primitive simplicity of its elements and the eternal pathos of the human tragedy that it sought to symbolize . [He]117-dorian gray loved to kneel down on the cold marble pavement and watch [the priest]933-the priest , in [his]933-the priest stiff flowered dalmatic , slowly and with white hands moving aside the veil of the tabernacle , or raising aloft the jewelled , lantern - shaped monstrance with that pallid wafer that at times , one would fain think , is indeed the " _ panis c lestis _ , "[933-the priest] the bread of angels , or , robed in the garments of the Passion of [Christ]224-christ , breaking the Host into the chalice and smiting [his]117-dorian gray breast for [his]117-dorian gray sins . The fuming censers that [the grave boys]1171-the grave boys , in [their]1171-the grave boys lace and scarlet , tossed into the air like great gilt flowers had [their]1171-the grave boys subtle fascination for [him]117-dorian gray . As [he]117-dorian gray passed out , [he]117-dorian gray used to look with wonder at the black confessionals and long to sit in the dim shadow of one of [them]1172-them and listen to [men]2041-men and [women]2058-women whispering through the worn grating the true story of [their]1175-their lives .

But [he]117-dorian gray never fell into the error of arresting [his]117-dorian gray intellectual development by any formal acceptance of creed or system , or of mistaking , for [a house in which to live]1176-a house in which to live , [an inn that is but suitable for the sojourn of a night]1177-an inn that is but suitable for the sojourn of a night , or for a few hours of a night in which there are no stars and the moon is in travail . Mysticism , with its marvellous power of making common things strange to [us]1178-us , and the subtle antinomianism that always seems to accompany it , moved [him]117-dorian gray for a season ; and for a season [he]117-dorian gray inclined to the materialistic doctrines of the _ Darwinismus _ movement in [Germany]51-germany , and found a curious pleasure in tracing the thoughts and passions of [men]2041-men to some pearly cell in the brain , or some white nerve in the body , delighting in the conception of the absolute dependence of the spirit on certain physical conditions , morbid or healthy , normal or diseased . Yet , as has been said of [him]117-dorian gray before , no theory of life seemed to [him]117-dorian gray to be of any importance compared with life itself . [He]117-dorian gray felt keenly conscious of how barren all intellectual speculation is when separated from action and experiment . [He]117-dorian gray knew that the senses , no less than [the soul]1180-the soul , have [their]2041-men spiritual mysteries to reveal .

And so [he]117-dorian gray would now study perfumes and the secrets of [their]1172-them manufacture , distilling heavily scented oils and burning odorous gums from [the East]52-the east . [He]117-dorian gray saw that there was no mood of the mind that had not its counterpart in the sensuous life , and set [himself]117-dorian gray to discover [their]1181-their true relations , wondering what there was in frankincense that made one mystical , and in ambergris that stirred one s passions , and in violets that woke the memory of dead romances , and in musk that troubled the brain , and in champak that stained the imagination ; and seeking often to elaborate a real psychology of perfumes , and to estimate the several influences of sweet - smelling roots and scented , pollen - laden flowers ; of aromatic balms and of [dark and fragrant woods]1182-dark and fragrant woods ; of spikenard , that sickens ; of hovenia , that makes [men]2041-men mad ; and of [aloes , that are said to be able to expel melancholy from the soul]1184-aloes , that are said to be able to expel melancholy from the soul .

At another time [he]117-dorian gray devoted [himself]117-dorian gray entirely to music , and in [a long latticed room]1185-a long latticed room , with a vermilion - and - gold ceiling and walls of olive - green lacquer , [he]117-dorian gray used to give curious concerts in which [mad gipsies]1186-mad gipsies tore wild music from [little zithers , or grave , yellow - shawled Tunisians plucked at the strained strings of monstrous lutes]1187-little zithers , or grave , yellow - shawled tunisians plucked at the strained strings of monstrous lutes , while [grinning Negroes]1188-grinning negroes beat monotonously upon copper drums and , crouching upon scarlet mats , [slim turbaned Indians]225-slim turbaned indians blew through long pipes of reed or brass and charmed or feigned to charm great hooded snakes and horrible horned adders . The harsh intervals and shrill discords of barbaric music stirred [him]117-dorian gray at times when [Schubert]226-schubert s grace , and [Chopin]227-chopin s beautiful sorrows , and the mighty harmonies of [Beethoven]228-beethoven [himself]228-beethoven , fell unheeded on [his]117-dorian gray ear . [He]117-dorian gray collected together from [all parts of [the world]1908-the world]1189-all parts of the world the strangest instruments that could be found , either in [the tombs of [dead nations]1192-dead nations]1191-the tombs of dead nations or among [the few savage tribes that have survived contact with [Western civilizations]1194-western civilizations]1193-the few savage tribes that have survived contact with western civilizations , and loved to touch and try them . [He]117-dorian gray had the mysterious _ juruparis _ of [the Rio Negro Indians]1195-the rio negro indians , that [women]2058-women are not allowed to look at and that [even youths]1197-even youths may not see till [they]1197-even youths have been subjected to fasting and scourging , and the earthen jars of the Peruvians that have the shrill cries of birds , and flutes of human bones such as [Alfonso de Ovalle]229-alfonso de ovalle heard in [Chile]53-chile , and the sonorous green jaspers that are found near [Cuzco]54-cuzco and give forth a note of singular sweetness . [He]117-dorian gray had painted gourds filled with pebbles that rattled when they were shaken ; the long _ clarin _ of [the Mexicans]1198-the mexicans , into which [the performer]1199-the performer does not blow , but through which [he]1199-the performer inhales the air ; the harsh _ ture _ of [the Amazon tribes]1200-the amazon tribes , that is sounded by [the sentinels who sit all day long in high trees , and can be heard]1201-the sentinels who sit all day long in high trees , and can be heard , it is said , at a distance of three leagues ; [the _ teponaztli _ , that has two vibrating tongues of wood and is beaten with sticks]1202-the _ teponaztli _ , that has two vibrating tongues of wood and is beaten with sticks that are smeared with an elastic gum obtained from the milky juice of plants ; the _ yotl_-bells of [the Aztecs , that are hung in clusters like grapes]1203-the aztecs , that are hung in clusters like grapes ; and a huge cylindrical drum , covered with the skins of great serpents , like the one that [Bernal Diaz]230-bernal diaz saw when [he]230-bernal diaz went with [Cortes]231-cortes into [the Mexican temple]1204-the mexican temple , and of whose doleful sound [he]230-bernal diaz has left [us]1205-us so vivid a description . The fantastic character of these instruments fascinated [him]117-dorian gray , and [he]117-dorian gray felt a curious delight in the thought that art , like [Nature]190-nature , has [her]190-nature monsters , things of bestial shape and with hideous voices . Yet , after some time , [he]117-dorian gray wearied of [them]1206-them , and would sit in [his]117-dorian gray box at [the opera]959-the opera , either alone or with [Lord Henry]120-lord henry , listening in rapt pleasure to " [Tannhauser]232-tannhauser "[120-lord henry] and seeing in the prelude to that great work of art a presentation of the tragedy of [his]117-dorian gray own soul .

On one occasion [he]117-dorian gray took up the study of jewels , and appeared at a costume ball as [Anne de Joyeuse]233-anne de joyeuse , [Admiral of [France]55-france]1208-admiral of france , in a dress covered with five hundred and sixty pearls . This taste enthralled [him]117-dorian gray for years , and , indeed , may be said never to have left [him]117-dorian gray . [He]117-dorian gray would often spend a whole day settling and resettling in [their]1206-them cases the various stones that [he]117-dorian gray had collected , such as the olive - green chrysoberyl that turns red by lamplight , the cymophane with its wirelike line of silver , the pistachio - coloured peridot , rose - pink and wine - yellow topazes , carbuncles of fiery scarlet with tremulous , four - rayed stars , flame - red cinnamon - stones , orange and violet spinels , and amethysts with their alternate layers of ruby and sapphire . [He]117-dorian gray loved the red gold of the sunstone , and the moonstone s pearly whiteness , and the broken rainbow of the milky opal . [He]117-dorian gray procured from [Amsterdam]234-amsterdam three emeralds of extraordinary size and richness of colour , and had a turquoise _ de la vieille roche _ that was the envy of [all the connoisseurs]1209-all the connoisseurs .

[He]117-dorian gray discovered wonderful stories , also , about jewels . In [Alphonso]229-alfonso de ovalle s Clericalis Disciplina a serpent was mentioned with eyes of [real jacinth]1210-real jacinth , and in the romantic history of [Alexander]235-alexander , [the Conqueror of Emathia]1211-the conqueror of emathia was said to have found in [the vale of [Jordan]56-jordan snakes " with collars of real emeralds growing on [their]3000-the vale of jordan snakes " with collars of real emeralds growing on their backs backs]3000-the vale of jordan snakes " with collars of real emeralds growing on their backs . "[229-alfonso de ovalle] There was a gem in the brain of the dragon , [Philostratus]236-philostratus told [us]1212-us , and " by the exhibition of golden letters and a scarlet robe "[229-alfonso de ovalle] the monster could be thrown into a magical sleep and slain . According to [the great alchemist]1213-the great alchemist , [Pierre de Boniface]237-pierre de boniface , the diamond rendered [a man]380-a man invisible , and the agate of [India]57-india made [him]380-a man eloquent . [The cornelian]1215-the cornelian appeased anger , and [the hyacinth]1216-the hyacinth provoked sleep , and the amethyst drove away the fumes of wine . The garnet cast out demons , and the hydropicus deprived the moon of [her]1217-her colour . The selenite waxed and waned with the moon , and the meloceus , that discovers [thieves]1218-thieves , could be affected only by the blood of [kids]1219-kids . [Leonardus Camillus]238-leonardus camillus had seen a white stone taken from the brain of a newly killed toad , that was a certain antidote against poison . The bezoar , that was found in the heart of the Arabian deer , was a charm that could cure the plague . In the nests of Arabian birds was the aspilates , that , according to [Democritus]239-democritus , kept [the wearer]1220-the wearer from any danger by fire .

[The King of [Ceilan]240-ceilan]1221-the king of ceilan rode through [[his]1221-the king of ceilan city]1222-his city with a large ruby in [his]1221-the king of ceilan hand , as the ceremony of [his]1221-the king of ceilan coronation . The gates of [the palace of [John the Priest]241-john the priest]1223-the palace of john the priest were " made of sardius , with the horn of the horned snake inwrought , so that [no man]2631-no man might bring poison within . "[1221-the king of ceilan] Over [the gable]1224-the gable were " two golden apples , in which were two carbuncles , "[1221-the king of ceilan] so that the gold might shine by day and the carbuncles by night . In Lodge s strange romance [A Margarite of [America]18-america]58-a margarite of america , it was stated that in [the chamber of [the queen]2221-the queen]1225-the chamber of the queen one could behold " [all the chaste ladies of [the world]1908-the world]3002-all the chaste ladies of the world , inchased out of silver , looking through fair mirrours of chrysolites , carbuncles , sapphires , and greene emeraults . "[242-marco polo] [Marco Polo]242-marco polo had seen [the inhabitants of]1227-the inhabitants of [Zipangu]59-zipangu place rose - coloured pearls in the mouths of the dead . [A sea - monster]1228-a sea - monster had been enamoured of the pearl that [the diver]1229-the diver brought to [King Perozes]243-king perozes , and had slain [the thief]1230-the thief , and mourned for seven moons over its loss . When [the Huns]244-the huns lured [the king]1231-the king into [the great pit]1232-the great pit , [he]1231-the king flung it away [Procopius]245-procopius tells the story nor was it ever found again , though [the Emperor Anastasius]1233-the emperor anastasius offered five hundred - weight of gold pieces for it . [The King of [Malabar]60-malabar]1234-the king of malabar had shown to a certain [Venetian]246-venetian a rosary of three hundred and four pearls , one for [every god that [he]1234-the king of malabar worshipped]1235-every god that he worshipped .

When [the Duke de Valentinois]247-the duke de valentinois , [son of [Alexander VI]235-alexander .]1236-son of alexander vi . , visited [Louis XII]248-louis xii . of [France]55-france , [his]247-the duke de valentinois horse was loaded with gold leaves , according to [Brantome]249-brantome , and [his]247-the duke de valentinois cap had double rows of rubies that threw out a great light . [[Charles]250-charles of [England]5-england]1237-charles of england had ridden in stirrups hung with four hundred and twenty - one diamonds . [Richard II]251-richard ii had a coat , valued at thirty thousand marks , which was covered with balas rubies . [Hall]252-hall described [Henry VIII]253-henry viii . , on [his]253-henry viii way to [the Tower]1238-the tower previous to [his]253-henry viii coronation , as wearing " a jacket of raised gold , the placard embroidered with diamonds and other rich stones , and a great bauderike about [his]253-henry viii neck of large balasses . "[253-henry viii] [The favourites of [James I]183-jim]1239-the favourites of james i wore ear - rings of emeralds set in gold filigrane . [Edward II]254-edward ii gave to [Piers Gaveston]255-piers gaveston a suit of red - gold armour studded with jacinths , a collar of gold roses set with turquoise - stones , and a skull - cap _ parsem _ with pearls . [Henry II]256-henry ii . wore jewelled gloves reaching to the elbow , and had a hawk - glove sewn with twelve rubies and fifty - two great orients . The ducal hat of [Charles the Rash]250-charles , [the last Duke of [Burgundy]61-burgundy of [his]250-charles race]1240-the last duke of burgundy of his race , was hung with pear - shaped pearls and studded with sapphires .

How exquisite life had once been ! How gorgeous in its pomp and decoration ! Even to read of the luxury of the dead was wonderful .

Then [he]253-henry viii turned [his]253-henry viii attention to embroideries and to the tapestries that performed the office of frescoes in [the chill rooms of [the northern nations of [Europe]62-europe]1242-the northern nations of europe]1241-the chill rooms of the northern nations of europe . As [he]253-henry viii investigated the subject and [he]253-henry viii always had an extraordinary faculty of becoming absolutely absorbed for the moment in whatever [he]253-henry viii took up [he]253-henry viii was almost saddened by the reflection of the ruin that time brought on beautiful and wonderful things . [He]253-henry viii , at any rate , had escaped that . Summer followed summer , and the yellow jonquils bloomed and died many times , and nights of horror repeated the story of their shame , but [he]253-henry viii was unchanged . No winter marred [his]253-henry viii face or stained [his]253-henry viii flowerlike bloom . How different it was with material things ! Where had [they]1243-they passed to ? Where was the great crocus - coloured robe , on which [the gods]1932-the gods fought against [the giants]1245-the giants , that had been worked by [brown girls]1246-brown girls for the pleasure of [Athena]257-athena ? Where [the huge velarium that [Nero]258-nero had stretched across the Colosseum at [Rome]63-rome]1247-the huge velarium that nero had stretched across the colosseum at rome , that Titan sail of purple on which was represented the starry sky , and [Apollo]259-apollo driving [a chariot drawn by white , gilt - reined steeds]1248-a chariot drawn by white , gilt - reined steeds ? [He]253-henry viii longed to see the curious table - napkins wrought for [the Priest of the Sun]1249-the priest of the sun , on which were displayed all the dainties and viands that could be wanted for a feast ; the mortuary cloth of [King Chilperic]260-king chilperic , with its three hundred golden bees ; the fantastic robes that excited the indignation of [the Bishop of [Pontus]64-pontus]1250-the bishop of pontus and were figured with " lions , panthers , bears , dogs , forests , rocks , [hunters]3004-hunters all , in fact , that [a painter]3005-a painter can copy from nature "[1250-the bishop of pontus] ; and the coat that [Charles of Orleans]261-charles of orleans once wore , on the sleeves of which were embroidered the verses of a song beginning " _ Madame , je suis tout joyeux _ , "[1250-the bishop of pontus] the musical accompaniment of the words being wrought in gold thread , and each note , of square shape in those days , formed with four pearls . [He]253-henry viii read of [the room that was prepared at [the palace at [Rheims]65-rheims]1252-the palace at rheims]1251-the room that was prepared at the palace at rheims for the use of [Queen Joan of Burgundy]262-queen joan of burgundy and was decorated with " thirteen hundred and twenty - one parrots , made in broidery , and blazoned with [the king]1231-the king s arms , and five hundred and sixty - one butterflies , whose wings were similarly ornamented with the arms of [the queen]2221-the queen , the whole worked in gold . "[263-catherine de medicis] [Catherine de Medicis]263-catherine de medicis had a mourning - bed made for [her]263-catherine de medicis of black velvet powdered with crescents and suns . [Its]263-catherine de medicis curtains were of damask , with leafy wreaths and garlands , figured upon a gold and silver ground , and fringed along the edges with broideries of pearls , and [it]263-catherine de medicis stood in [a room]1253-a room hung with rows of [the queen]2221-the queen s devices in cut black velvet upon cloth of silver . [Louis XIV]264-louis xiv . had gold embroidered caryatides fifteen feet high in [[his]264-louis xiv apartment]1255-his apartment . The state bed of [Sobieski]265-sobieski , [King of [Poland]66-poland]1256-king of poland , was made of Smyrna gold brocade embroidered in turquoises with verses from the Koran . Its supports were of silver gilt , beautifully chased , and profusely set with enamelled and jewelled medallions . It had been taken from [the Turkish camp]1257-the turkish camp before [Vienna]67-vienna , and the standard of [Mohammed]266-mohammed had stood beneath the tremulous gilt of [its]263-catherine de medicis canopy .

And so , for a whole year , [he]266-mohammed sought to accumulate the most exquisite specimens that [he]266-mohammed could find of textile and embroidered work , getting the dainty Delhi muslins , finely wrought with gold - thread palmates and stitched over with iridescent beetles wings ; the Dacca gauzes , that from their transparency are known in [the East]52-the east as " woven air , "[266-mohammed] and " running water , "[266-mohammed] and " evening dew "[266-mohammed] ; strange figured cloths from [Java]68-java ; elaborate yellow Chinese hangings ; books bound in tawny satins or fair blue silks and wrought with _ fleurs - de - lis _ , birds and images ; veils of _ lacis _ worked in [Hungary]69-hungary point ; Sicilian brocades and stiff Spanish velvets ; Georgian work , with its gilt coins , and Japanese _ Foukousas _ , with their green - toned golds and their marvellously plumaged birds .

[He]266-mohammed had a special passion , also , for ecclesiastical vestments , as indeed [he]266-mohammed had for everything connected with the service of [the Church]1919-the church . In the long cedar chests that lined the west gallery of [[his]266-mohammed house]1259-his house , [he]266-mohammed had stored away many rare and beautiful specimens of what is really the raiment of [the Bride of Christ]1260-the bride of christ , who must wear purple and jewels and fine linen that [she]1260-the bride of christ may hide the pallid macerated body that is worn by the suffering that [she]1260-the bride of christ seeks for and wounded by self - inflicted pain . [He]266-mohammed possessed a gorgeous cope of crimson silk and gold - thread damask , figured with a repeating pattern of golden pomegranates set in six - petalled formal blossoms , beyond which on either side was the pine - apple device wrought in seed - pearls . The orphreys were divided into panels representing scenes from the life of [the Virgin]1261-the virgin , and the coronation of [the Virgin]1261-the virgin was figured in coloured silks upon the hood . This was Italian work of the fifteenth century . Another cope was of green velvet , embroidered with heart - shaped groups of acanthus - leaves , from which spread long - stemmed white blossoms , the details of which were picked out with silver thread and coloured crystals . The morse bore a seraph s head in gold - thread raised work . [The orphreys]1263-the orphreys were woven in a diaper of red and gold silk , and were starred with medallions of [many saints]1264-many saints and [martyrs]1265-martyrs , among whom was [St. Sebastian]267-st. sebastian . [He]266-mohammed had chasubles , also , of amber - coloured silk , and blue silk and gold brocade , and yellow silk damask and cloth of gold , figured with representations of the Passion and Crucifixion of [Christ]224-christ , and embroidered with lions and peacocks and other emblems ; dalmatics of white satin and pink silk damask , decorated with tulips and dolphins and _ fleurs - de - lis _ ; altar frontals of crimson velvet and blue linen ; and many corporals , chalice - veils , and sudaria . In the mystic offices to which such things were put , there was something that quickened [his]266-mohammed imagination .

For these treasures , and everything that [he]266-mohammed collected in [[his]266-mohammed lovely house]1266-his lovely house , were to be to [him]266-mohammed means of forgetfulness , modes by which [he]266-mohammed could escape , for a season , from the fear that seemed to [him]266-mohammed at times to be almost too great to be borne . Upon the walls of [the lonely locked room where [he]266-mohammed had spent so much of [his]266-mohammed boyhood]1267-the lonely locked room where he had spent so much of his boyhood , [he]266-mohammed had hung with [his]266-mohammed own hands the terrible portrait whose changing features showed [him]266-mohammed the real degradation of [his]266-mohammed life , and in front of it had draped the purple - and - gold pall as a curtain . For weeks [he]266-mohammed would not go [there]1904-there , would forget the hideous painted thing , and get back [his]266-mohammed light heart , [his]266-mohammed wonderful joyousness , [his]266-mohammed passionate absorption in mere existence . Then , suddenly , some night [he]266-mohammed would creep out of [the house]425-the house , go down to dreadful places near [Blue Gate Fields]70-blue gate fields , and stay [there]1904-there , day after day , until [he]266-mohammed was driven away . On [his]266-mohammed return [he]266-mohammed would sit in front of the picture , sometimes loathing it and [himself]266-mohammed , but filled , at other times , with that pride of individualism that is half the fascination of sin , and smiling with secret pleasure at the misshapen shadow that had to bear the burden that should have been [his]266-mohammed own .

After a few years [he]266-mohammed could not endure to be long out of [England]5-england , and gave up [the villa that [he]266-mohammed had shared at [Trouville]71-trouville with [Lord Henry]120-lord henry]1271-the villa that he had shared at trouville with lord henry , as well as [the little white walled - in house at [Algiers]72-algiers where [they]1273-they had more than once spent the winter]1272-the little white walled - in house at algiers where they had more than once spent the winter . [He]266-mohammed hated to be separated from the picture that was such a part of [his]266-mohammed life , and was also afraid that during [his]266-mohammed absence [some one]1960-some one might gain access to [the room]386-the room , in spite of the elaborate bars that [he]266-mohammed had caused to be placed upon the door .

[He]266-mohammed was quite conscious that this would tell [them]1273-they nothing . It was true that the portrait still preserved , under all the foulness and ugliness of the face , its marked likeness to [himself]266-mohammed ; but what could [they]1273-they learn from that ? [He]266-mohammed would laugh at [any one who tried to taunt [him]266-mohammed]1276-any one who tried to taunt him . [He]266-mohammed had not painted it . What was it to [him]266-mohammed how vile and full of shame it looked ? Even if [he]266-mohammed told [them]1273-they , would [they]1273-they believe it ?

Yet [he]266-mohammed was afraid . Sometimes when [he]266-mohammed was down at [[his]266-mohammed great house in [Nottinghamshire]73-nottinghamshire]1277-his great house in nottinghamshire , entertaining [the fashionable young men of [his]266-mohammed own rank who were [[his]266-mohammed chief companions]1279-his chief companions]1278-the fashionable young men of his own rank who were his chief companions , and astounding [the county]1280-the county by the wanton luxury and gorgeous splendour of [his]266-mohammed mode of life , [he]266-mohammed would suddenly leave [[his]266-mohammed guests]1131-his guests and rush back to [town]1935-town to see that the door had not been tampered with and that the picture was still there . What if it should be stolen ? The mere thought made [him]266-mohammed cold with horror . Surely [the world]1908-the world would know [his]266-mohammed secret then . Perhaps [the world]1908-the world already suspected it .

For , while [he]266-mohammed fascinated [many]1285-many , there were not a few who distrusted [him]266-mohammed . [He]266-mohammed was very nearly blackballed at [a West End]1286-a west end club of which [his]266-mohammed birth and social position fully entitled [him]266-mohammed to become [a member]1287-a member , and it was said that on one occasion , when [he]266-mohammed was brought by [a friend]2002-a friend into [the smoking - room of [the Churchill]74-the churchill]1289-the smoking - room of the churchill , [the Duke of [Berwick]302-berwick]744-the duke of berwick and [another gentleman]1291-another gentleman got up in a marked manner and went out . Curious stories became current about [him]266-mohammed after [he]266-mohammed had passed [his]266-mohammed twenty - fifth year . It was rumoured that [he]266-mohammed had been seen brawling with [foreign sailors]1292-foreign sailors in [a low den in [the distant parts of [Whitechapel]8-whitechapel]1294-the distant parts of whitechapel]1293-a low den in the distant parts of whitechapel , and that [he]266-mohammed consorted with [thieves]1218-thieves and [coiners]1296-coiners and knew the mysteries of [their]1297-their trade . [His]266-mohammed extraordinary absences became notorious , and , when [he]266-mohammed used to reappear again in [society]1127-society , [men]2041-men would whisper to each other in corners , or pass [him]266-mohammed with a sneer , or look at [him]266-mohammed with cold searching eyes , as though [they]2041-men were determined to discover [his]266-mohammed secret .

Of such insolences and attempted slights [he]266-mohammed , of course , took no notice , and in the opinion of [most people]2291-most people [his]266-mohammed frank debonair manner , [his]266-mohammed charming boyish smile , and the infinite grace of that wonderful youth that seemed never to leave [him]266-mohammed , were in [themselves]2041-men a sufficient answer to the calumnies , for so [they]2041-men termed them , that were circulated about [him]266-mohammed . It was remarked , however , that [some of those who had been most intimate with [him]266-mohammed]1301-some of those who had been most intimate with him appeared , after a time , to shun [him]266-mohammed . [Women who had wildly adored [him]266-mohammed , and for [his]266-mohammed sake had braved all social censure and set convention at defiance]1302-women who had wildly adored him , and for his sake had braved all social censure and set convention at defiance , were seen to grow pallid with shame or horror if [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray entered [the room]386-the room .

Yet these whispered scandals only increased in the eyes of many [his]266-mohammed strange and dangerous charm . [His]266-mohammed great wealth was a certain element of security . Society civilized society , at least is never very ready to believe anything to the detriment of [those who are both rich and fascinating]1304-those who are both rich and fascinating . [It]1305-it feels instinctively that manners are of more importance than morals , and , in its opinion , the highest respectability is of much less value than the possession of [a good _ chef _]1306-a good _ chef _ . And , after all , it is a very poor consolation to be told that [the man who has given [one a bad dinner]1308-one a bad dinner , or poor wine , is irreproachable in [his]1307-the man who has given one a bad dinner , or poor wine , is irreproachable in his private life private life]1307-the man who has given one a bad dinner , or poor wine , is irreproachable in his private life . Even the cardinal virtues can not atone for half - cold _ entr es _ , as [Lord Henry]120-lord henry remarked once , in a discussion on the subject , and there is possibly a good deal to be said for [his]120-lord henry view . For the canons of good society are , or should be , the same as the canons of art . Form is absolutely essential to it . It should have the dignity of a ceremony , as well as its unreality , and should combine the insincere character of a romantic play with the wit and beauty that make such plays delightful to [us]1309-us . Is insincerity such a terrible thing ? [I]0-perles ruisselant think not . It is merely a method by which [we]1309-us can multiply [our]1309-us personalities .

Such , at any rate , was [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray s opinion . [He]117-dorian gray used to wonder at the shallow psychology of [those who conceive the ego in [man]364-man]1310-those who conceive the ego in man as a thing simple , permanent , reliable , and of one essence . To [him]117-dorian gray , [man]364-man was [a being with myriad lives and myriad sensations]1313-a being with myriad lives and myriad sensations , [a complex multiform creature that bore within itself strange legacies of thought and passion , and whose very flesh was tainted with the monstrous maladies of the dead]1314-a complex multiform creature that bore within itself strange legacies of thought and passion , and whose very flesh was tainted with the monstrous maladies of the dead . [He]117-dorian gray loved to stroll through [the gaunt cold picture - gallery of [[his]117-dorian gray country house]1316-his country house]1315-the gaunt cold picture - gallery of his country house and look at the various portraits of those whose blood flowed in [his]117-dorian gray veins . Here was [Philip Herbert]268-philip herbert , described by [Francis Osborne]269-francis , in [his]269-francis Memoires on the Reigns of [Queen Elizabeth]270-queen elizabeth and [King James]271-king james , as one who was " caressed by [the Court]3008-the court for [his]268-philip herbert handsome face , which kept [him]268-philip herbert not long company . "[268-philip herbert] Was it [young Herbert]268-philip herbert s life that [he]117-dorian gray sometimes led ? Had some strange poisonous germ crept from body to body till it had reached [his]117-dorian gray own ? Was it some dim sense of that ruined grace that had made [him]117-dorian gray so suddenly , and almost without cause , give utterance , in [[Basil Hallward]121-basil s studio]612-basil hallward s studio , to the mad prayer that had so changed [his]117-dorian gray life ? Here , in gold - embroidered red doublet , jewelled surcoat , and gilt - edged ruff and wristbands , stood [Sir Anthony Sherard]272-sir anthony sherard , with [his]272-sir anthony sherard silver - and - black armour piled at [his]272-sir anthony sherard feet . What had [this man]2580-this man s legacy been ? Had [the lover of Giovanna of [Naples]76-naples]1319-the lover of giovanna of naples bequeathed [him]2580-this man some inheritance of sin and shame ? Were [his]2580-this man own actions merely the dreams that [the dead man]1320-the dead man had not dared to realize ? Here , from the fading canvas , smiled [Lady Elizabeth Devereux]273-lady elizabeth devereux , in [her]273-lady elizabeth devereux gauze hood , pearl stomacher , and pink slashed sleeves . A flower was in [her]273-lady elizabeth devereux right hand , and [her]273-lady elizabeth devereux left clasped an enamelled collar of white and damask roses . On a table by [her]273-lady elizabeth devereux side lay a mandolin and an apple . There were large green rosettes upon [her]273-lady elizabeth devereux little pointed shoes . [He]117-dorian gray knew [her]273-lady elizabeth devereux life , and the strange stories that were told about [[her]273-lady elizabeth devereux lovers]1321-her lovers . Had [he]117-dorian gray something of [her]273-lady elizabeth devereux temperament in [him]117-dorian gray ? These oval , heavy - lidded eyes seemed to look curiously at [him]117-dorian gray . What of [George Willoughby]274-george willoughby , with [his]274-george willoughby powdered hair and fantastic patches ? How evil [he]274-george willoughby looked ! The face was saturnine and swarthy , and the sensual lips seemed to be twisted with disdain . Delicate lace ruffles fell over the lean yellow hands that were so overladen with rings . [He]117-dorian gray had been [a macaroni of the eighteenth century]1322-a macaroni of the eighteenth century , and [the friend , in [his]117-dorian gray youth , of [Lord Ferrars]275-lord ferrars]1323-the friend , in his youth , of lord ferrars . What of [the second Lord Beckenham]276-the second lord beckenham , [the companion of [the Prince Regent]1325-the prince regent in [his]276-the second lord beckenham wildest days]1324-the companion of the prince regent in his wildest days , and [one of [the witnesses]1327-the witnesses at the secret marriage with [Mrs. Fitzherbert]277-mrs. fitzherbert]1326-one of the witnesses at the secret marriage with mrs. fitzherbert ? How proud and handsome [he]117-dorian gray was , with [his]117-dorian gray chestnut curls and insolent pose ! What passions had [he]117-dorian gray bequeathed ? [The world]1908-the world had looked upon [him]117-dorian gray as infamous . [He]117-dorian gray had led the orgies at [Carlton House]77-carlton house . The star of the Garter glittered upon [his]117-dorian gray breast . Beside [him]117-dorian gray hung the portrait of [[his]117-dorian gray wife]2313-his wife , [a pallid , thin - lipped woman in black]1330-a pallid , thin - lipped woman in black . [Her]2313-his wife blood , also , stirred within [him]117-dorian gray . How curious it all seemed ! And [[his]117-dorian gray mother]2191-his mother with [her]2191-his mother Lady Hamilton face and [her]2191-his mother moist , wine - dashed lips [he]117-dorian gray knew what [he]117-dorian gray had got from [her]2191-his mother . [He]117-dorian gray had got from [her]2191-his mother [his]117-dorian gray beauty , and [his]117-dorian gray passion for the beauty of [others]1931-others . [She]2191-his mother laughed at [him]117-dorian gray in [her]2191-his mother loose Bacchante dress . There were vine leaves in [her]2191-his mother hair . The purple spilled from the cup [she]2191-his mother was holding . The carnations of the painting had withered , but the eyes were still wonderful in their depth and brilliancy of colour . They seemed to follow [him]117-dorian gray wherever [he]117-dorian gray went .

Yet [one]381-one had ancestors in literature as well as in [one s own race]1334-one s own race , nearer perhaps in type and temperament , many of [them]1335-them , and certainly with an influence of which [one]381-one was more absolutely conscious . There were times when it appeared to [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray that the whole of history was merely the record of [his]117-dorian gray own life , not as [he]117-dorian gray had lived it in act and circumstance , but as [his]117-dorian gray imagination had created it for [him]117-dorian gray , as it had been in [his]117-dorian gray brain and in [his]117-dorian gray passions . [He]117-dorian gray felt that [he]117-dorian gray had known [them]1337-their all , those strange terrible figures that had passed across the stage of [the world]1908-the world and made sin so marvellous and evil so full of subtlety . It seemed to [him]117-dorian gray that in some mysterious way [their]1337-their lives had been [his]117-dorian gray own .

[The hero of the wonderful novel that had so influenced [his]117-dorian gray life]1339-the hero of the wonderful novel that had so influenced his life had [himself]1339-the hero of the wonderful novel that had so influenced his life known this curious fancy . In the seventh chapter [he]117-dorian gray tells how , crowned with laurel , lest lightning might strike [him]117-dorian gray , [he]117-dorian gray had sat , as [Tiberius]278-tiberius , in [a garden at [Capri]78-capri]1340-a garden at capri , reading the shameful books of [Elephantis]279-elephantis , while [dwarfs]1341-dwarfs and peacocks strutted round [him]117-dorian gray and [the flute - player]1342-the flute - player mocked the swinger of the censer ; and , as [Caligula]280-caligula , had caroused with the green - shirted jockeys in [[their]1337-their stables]1343-their stables and supped in an ivory manger with a jewel - frontleted horse ; and , as [Domitian]281-domitian , had wandered through [a corridor lined with marble mirrors]1344-a corridor lined with marble mirrors , looking round with haggard eyes for the reflection of the dagger that was to end [his]281-domitian days , and sick with that ennui , that terrible _ t dium vit _ , that comes on [those to whom life denies nothing]1345-those to whom life denies nothing ; and had peered through a clear emerald at the red shambles of [the circus]1346-the circus and then , in a litter of pearl and purple drawn by silver - shod mules , been carried through [the Street of Pomegranates]1347-the street of pomegranates to [a House of Gold]1348-a house of gold and heard [men]2041-men cry on [Nero Caesar]258-nero as [he]258-nero passed by ; and , as [Elagabalus]282-elagabalus , had painted [his]282-elagabalus face with colours , and plied the distaff among [the women]2232-the women , and brought the Moon from [Carthage]79-carthage and given [her]2232-the women in mystic marriage to the Sun .

Over and over again [Dorian]117-dorian gray used to read this fantastic chapter , and the two chapters immediately following , in which , as in some curious tapestries or cunningly wrought enamels , were pictured the awful and beautiful forms of [those whom vice and blood and weariness had made monstrous or mad]1351-those whom vice and blood and weariness had made monstrous or mad : [Filippo]283-filippo , [Duke of [Milan]80-milan , who slew [[his]1352-duke of milan , who slew his wife and painted her lips with a scarlet poison that her lover might suck death from the dead thing he fondled wife]2313-his wife and painted [her]2313-his wife lips with a scarlet poison that [[her]2313-his wife lover]1354-her lover might suck death from the dead thing [he]1352-duke of milan , who slew his wife and painted her lips with a scarlet poison that her lover might suck death from the dead thing he fondled fondled]1352-duke of milan , who slew his wife and painted her lips with a scarlet poison that her lover might suck death from the dead thing he fondled ; [Pietro Barbi]284-pietro barbi , [the Venetian]1355-the venetian , known as [Paul the Second]1356-paul the second , who sought in [his]1356-paul the second vanity to assume the title of Formosus , and whose tiara , valued at two hundred thousand florins , was bought at the price of a terrible sin ; [Gian Maria Visconti]285-gian maria visconti , who used hounds to chase [living men]1357-living men and whose murdered body was covered with roses by [a harlot who had loved [him]1352-duke of milan , who slew his wife and painted her lips with a scarlet poison that her lover might suck death from the dead thing he fondled]1358-a harlot who had loved him ; [the Borgia]286-the borgia on [his]286-the borgia white horse , with [Fratricide]287-fratricide riding beside [him]286-the borgia and [his]286-the borgia mantle stained with the blood of [Perotto]288-perotto ; [Pietro Riario]289-pietro riario , [the young Cardinal Archbishop of [Florence]81-florence]1359-the young cardinal archbishop of florence , [child and minion of Sixtus IV .]1360-child and minion of sixtus iv . , whose beauty was equalled only by [his]286-the borgia debauchery , and who received Leonora of [Aragon]82-aragon in a pavilion of white and crimson silk , filled with nymphs and centaurs , and gilded [a boy that [he]286-the borgia might serve at the feast as [Ganymede]83-ganymede or [Hylas]84-hylas]1361-a boy that he might serve at the feast as ganymede or hylas ; [Ezzelin , whose melancholy could be cured only by the spectacle of death , and who had a passion for red blood]1362-ezzelin , whose melancholy could be cured only by the spectacle of death , and who had a passion for red blood , as [other men]2645-other men have for red wine [the son of [the Fiend]1365-the fiend]1364-the son of the fiend , as was reported , and [one who had cheated [[his]1366-one who had cheated his father at dice when gambling with him for his own soul father]493-his father at dice when gambling with [him]493-his father for [his]1366-one who had cheated his father at dice when gambling with him for his own soul own soul]1366-one who had cheated his father at dice when gambling with him for his own soul ; [Giambattista Cibo]290-giambattista cibo , who in mockery took the name of Innocent and into whose torpid veins the blood of [three lads]1368-three lads was infused by [a Jewish doctor]1369-a jewish doctor ; [Sigismondo Malatesta]291-sigismondo malatesta , [the lover of [Isotta]292-isotta]1370-the lover of isotta and [the lord of [Rimini]85-rimini , whose effigy was burned at [Rome]63-rome]1371-the lord of rimini , whose effigy was burned at rome as [the enemy of [God]134-god and [man]364-man , who strangled [Polyssena]293-polyssena with a napkin , and gave poison to [Ginevra d Este]294-ginevra d este in a cup of emerald , and in honour of a shameful passion built a pagan church for Christian worship]1372-the enemy of god and man , who strangled polyssena with a napkin , and gave poison to ginevra d este in a cup of emerald , and in honour of a shameful passion built a pagan church for christian worship ; [[Charles VI]295-charles vi . , who had so wildly adored [[his]295-charles vi brother s wife]1375-his brother s wife that [a leper]1376-a leper had warned [him]295-charles vi of the insanity that was coming on [him]295-charles vi , and who , when [his]295-charles vi brain had sickened and grown strange , could only be soothed by [Saracen cards painted with the images of love and death and madness]1377-saracen cards painted with the images of love and death and madness]1374-charles vi . , who had so wildly adored his brother s wife that a leper had warned him of the insanity that was coming on him , and who , when his brain had sickened and grown strange , could only be soothed by saracen cards painted with the images of love and death and madness ; and , in [his]295-charles vi trimmed jerkin and jewelled cap and acanthuslike curls , [Grifonetto Baglioni]296-grifonetto baglioni , who slew [Astorre]297-astorre with [his]295-charles vi [bride]1378-bride , and [Simonetto]298-simonetto with [his]295-charles vi page , and whose comeliness was such that , as [he]295-charles vi lay dying in [the yellow piazza of [Perugia]86-perugia]1379-the yellow piazza of perugia , [those who had hated [him]295-charles vi]1380-those who had hated him could not choose but weep , and [Atalanta]299-atalanta , who had cursed [him]295-charles vi , blessed [him]295-charles vi .

There was a horrible fascination in [them]1381-them all . [He]295-charles vi saw [them]1381-them at night , and they troubled [his]295-charles vi imagination in the day . [The Renaissance]300-the renaissance knew of strange manners of poisoning poisoning by a helmet and a lighted torch , by an embroidered glove and a jewelled fan , by a gilded pomander and by an amber chain . [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray had been poisoned by a book . There were moments when [he]117-dorian gray looked on evil simply as a mode through which [he]117-dorian gray could realize [his]117-dorian gray conception of the beautiful .

CHAPTER XII

It was on the ninth of November , the eve of [his]295-charles vi own thirty - eighth birthday , as [he]295-charles vi often remembered afterwards .

[He]295-charles vi was walking [home]2087-home about eleven o clock from [Lord Henry s]120-lord henry , where [he]295-charles vi had been dining , and was wrapped in heavy furs , as the night was cold and foggy . At [the corner of [Grosvenor Square]88-grosvenor square and [South Audley Street]44-south audley street]1383-the corner of grosvenor square and south audley street , [a man]380-a man passed [him]295-charles vi in the mist , walking very fast and with the collar of [his]380-a man grey ulster turned up . [He]380-a man had a bag in [his]380-a man hand . [Dorian]117-dorian gray recognized [him]380-a man . It was [Basil Hallward]121-basil . A strange sense of fear , for which [he]117-dorian gray could not account , came over [him]117-dorian gray . [He]117-dorian gray made no sign of recognition and went on quickly in the direction of [[his]117-dorian gray own house]1385-his own house .

But [Hallward]121-basil had seen [him]117-dorian gray . [Dorian]1386-dorian heard [him]121-basil first stopping on [the pavement]1387-the pavement and then hurrying after [him]121-basil . In a few moments , [his]121-basil hand was on [his]117-dorian gray arm .

" [Dorian]3009-dorian ! What an extraordinary piece of luck ! [I]117-dorian gray have been waiting for [you]3009-dorian in [[your]3009-dorian library]3010-your library ever since nine o clock . Finally [I]117-dorian gray took pity on [[your]3009-dorian tired servant]3011-your tired servant and told [him]3011-your tired servant to go to bed , as [he]3011-your tired servant let [me]117-dorian gray out . [I]117-dorian gray am off to [Paris]13-paris by [the midnight train]3012-the midnight train , and [I]117-dorian gray particularly wanted to see [you]3009-dorian before [I]117-dorian gray left . [I]117-dorian gray thought it was [you]3009-dorian , or rather [your]3009-dorian fur coat , as [you]3009-dorian passed [me]117-dorian gray . But [I]117-dorian gray wasn t quite sure . Didn t [you]3009-dorian recognize [me]117-dorian gray ? "[117-dorian gray]

" In this fog , [[my]117-dorian gray dear]1914-my dear [Basil]121-basil ? Why , [I]117-dorian gray can t even recognize [Grosvenor Square]88-grosvenor square . [I]117-dorian gray believe [[my]117-dorian gray house]3014-my house is somewhere about here , but [I]117-dorian gray don t feel at all certain about it . [I]117-dorian gray am sorry [you]3009-dorian are going away , as [I]117-dorian gray have not seen [you]3009-dorian for ages . But [I]117-dorian gray suppose [you]3009-dorian will be back soon ? "[117-dorian gray]

" No : [I]117-dorian gray am going to be out of [England]5-england for six months . [I]117-dorian gray intend to take a studio in [Paris]13-paris and shut [myself]117-dorian gray up till [I]117-dorian gray have finished a great picture [I]117-dorian gray have in [my]117-dorian gray head . However , it wasn t about [myself]117-dorian gray [I]117-dorian gray wanted to talk . Here [we]3015-we are at [your]3009-dorian door . Let [me]117-dorian gray come in for a moment . [I]117-dorian gray have something to say to [you]3009-dorian . "[117-dorian gray]

" [I]117-dorian gray shall be charmed . But won t [you]3009-dorian miss [[your]3009-dorian train]3016-your train ? "[117-dorian gray] said [Dorian Gray]117-dorian gray languidly as [he]117-dorian gray passed up the steps and opened the door with [his]117-dorian gray latch - key .

The lamplight struggled out through the fog , and [Hallward]121-basil looked at [his]121-basil watch . " [I]121-basil have heaps of time , "[121-basil] [he]121-basil answered . " [The train]3017-the train doesn t go till twelve - fifteen , and it is only just eleven . In fact , [I]121-basil was on [my]121-basil way to [the club]2210-the club to look for [you]3009-dorian , when [I]121-basil met [you]3009-dorian . [You]3009-dorian see , [I]121-basil shan t have any delay about luggage , as [I]121-basil have sent on [my]121-basil heavy things . All [I]121-basil have with [me]121-basil is in this bag , and [I]121-basil can easily get to [Victoria]165-victoria in twenty minutes . "[121-basil]

[Dorian]117-dorian gray looked at [him]117-dorian gray and smiled . " What a way for [a fashionable painter]3019-a fashionable painter to travel ! A Gladstone bag and an ulster ! Come in , or the fog will get into [the house]425-the house . And mind [you]3009-dorian don t talk about anything serious . Nothing is serious nowadays . At least nothing should be . "[117-dorian gray]

[Hallward]121-basil shook [his]121-basil head , as [he]121-basil entered , and followed [Dorian]117-dorian gray into [the library]887-the library . There was a bright wood fire blazing in the large open hearth . The lamps were lit , and an open Dutch silver spirit - case stood , with some siphons of soda - water and large cut - glass tumblers , on a little marqueterie table .

" [You]3009-dorian see [[your]3009-dorian servant]2933-your servant made [me]121-basil quite at [home]2087-home , [Dorian]3023-dorian . [He]2933-your servant gave [me]121-basil everything [I]121-basil wanted , including [your]3009-dorian best gold - tipped cigarettes . [He]2933-your servant is [a most hospitable creature]3024-a most hospitable creature . [I]121-basil like [him]2933-your servant much better than [the Frenchman [you]3009-dorian used to have]3025-the frenchman you used to have . What has become of [the Frenchman]3026-the frenchman , by the bye ? "[121-basil]

[Dorian]117-dorian gray shrugged [his]117-dorian gray shoulders . " [I]117-dorian gray believe [he]2933-your servant married [[Lady Radley]219-lady radley s maid]3027-lady radley s maid , and has established [her]3027-lady radley s maid in [Paris]13-paris as [an English dressmaker]3028-an english dressmaker . _ Anglomanie _ is very fashionable over there now , [I]117-dorian gray hear . It seems silly of [the French]301-the french , doesn t it ? But do [you]3009-dorian know ? [he]2933-your servant was not at all [a bad servant]3029-a bad servant . [I]117-dorian gray never liked [him]2933-your servant , but [I]117-dorian gray had nothing to complain about . [One]381-one often imagines things that are quite absurd . [He]2933-your servant was really very devoted to [me]117-dorian gray and seemed quite sorry when [he]2933-your servant went away . Have another brandy - and - soda ? Or would [you]3009-dorian like hock - and - seltzer ? [I]117-dorian gray always take hock - and - seltzer [myself]117-dorian gray . There is sure to be some in [the next room]1097-the next room . "[117-dorian gray]

" Thanks , [I]389-the painter won t have anything more , "[389-the painter] said [the painter]389-the painter , taking [his]389-the painter cap and coat off and throwing them on the bag that [he]389-the painter had placed in the corner . " And now , [[my]389-the painter dear fellow]1907-my dear fellow , [I]389-the painter want to speak to [you]3009-dorian seriously . Don t frown like that . [You]3009-dorian make it so much more difficult for [me]389-the painter . "[389-the painter]

" What is it all about ? "[1390-dorian] cried [Dorian]1390-dorian in [his]1390-dorian petulant way , flinging [himself]1390-dorian down on the sofa . " [I]1390-dorian hope it is not about [myself]1390-dorian . [I]1390-dorian am tired of [myself]1390-dorian to - night . [I]1390-dorian should like to be [somebody else]3033-somebody else . "[1390-dorian]

" It is about [yourself]3009-dorian , "[121-basil] answered [Hallward]121-basil in [his]121-basil grave deep voice , " and [I]121-basil must say it to [you]3009-dorian . [I]121-basil shall only keep [you]3009-dorian half an hour . "[121-basil]

[Dorian]117-dorian gray sighed and lit a cigarette . " Half an hour ! "[117-dorian gray] [he]117-dorian gray murmured .

" It is not much to ask of [you]3009-dorian , [Dorian]3034-dorian , and it is entirely for [your]3009-dorian own sake that [I]1390-dorian am speaking .
